Humans wanting to push the red button once in a while can probably be explained by the class of problems called multi-armed bandit problems. The idea between this general problem is, there are many slot machines with unknown probabilities and unknown costs. You can only pull one slot machine at a time. If you pull a slot machine you either get a payout or a loss. You can't just pull a few different slots and keep picking the one that wins, because it's possible that you won on a low probability. The human is balancing information gathering with payout, in hopes of a higher payout later. What the human is probably incorrectly assuming for pressing buttons is some correlation between the button they press, and the outcome they receive.

An additional problem with stock markets is that if there were any true experts, the trades they make would shift prices so no further profit can be extracted. So while you may be sure that a particular company is going to do well, the price probably has adjusted already. On the other hand, if you only had passive funds and no one that tries to pick stocks, you would end up with truly random prices so even a crude stock picker could make money. So the "truth" in my view is that stock pickers can achieve a very small positive additional return, but the fees they charge to fund investors are for some reason outsized so the investor ends up doing worse than investing in a passive fund. The high fees are probably caused by irrationality: people believe that the experts will be able to deliver increased returns.

I think these 4 things make a master (before watching the video):

Understanding. Technique. Experience. Practice.
Understanding means being able to explain. Technique is being able to show.
Experience is being confident.
Practice is being proficient.

WHAT IT TAKES TO BE AN EXPERT
To become an expert, you have to practice for thousands of hours in the uncomfortable zone, attempting the things you can't do quite yet. At its core, expertise is recognition, and recognition comes from the incredible amount of highly structured information stored in long-term memory.

To build that memory, requires four things:
1. A valid environment.
2. Many repetitions: Repeated Experiences.
3. Timely Feedback: Repeated attempts with feedback.
4. And thousands of hours of Deliberate Practice:
- This means: Don't get too comfortable. Do challenging things, practice at the edge of your ability, pushing beyond your comfort zone.

When those criteria are met, human performance is astonishing.

Feedback is how you learn. I made some errors on a test; but the test was submitted and closed meaning that was it. Leaving me with no idea of what I got wrong. And hence what I needed to improve. The score didn't matter; not being able to learn from my mistakes did.

On the other hand, various online homework systems allowed the student to submit an answer and they would get an immediate result indicating if it was right or wrong. And could try again. I learned a good deal - and far more from the mistakes I made when I had to go back and rethink what I was doing than any of the immediate "correct!" responses.

And one thing I learned was that I needed to take a break. I was making repetitive stupid mistakes like typing "3" instead of "5". Without immediate feedback, I would never have stopped to pay more attention to correcting that issue.

I've been a programmer now for 3 years. The first two years were difficult. At the start of the third year I fealt like an utterly terrable engineer.

What I did have however was a limited self diagnostic ability. I knew I wasn't good at a lot of things. I knew this effected the quality and timlyness of my work. I wrote these down on a piece of paper and handed it to my manager.

He arranged a meeting with myslef, him and a HR rep. We discussed at great length, each point on my list. We went over each of my concerns, his appraisal of each point and then devised a plan of action for improvement. At the end we agreed to revisit the list every fortnight and see if it had an impact.

First couple of months = things on the list didn't get any worse. No major improvement either. I fealt unhappy with progress but my assigned mentors persisted and we adjusted my plan of action to suit the changing landscape

Following few months = the revised plan was more effective, my continued efforts to adapt, learn and grow were starting to show. I fealt happier with my performance

Past the halve way point = many of my issues that were more manageable had been resolved leaving some more habitual shortcomings. Seeing these same few over and over, fortnight after fortnight was distressing. I decided to start intense self study

Nest a year in = through spending substantial amounts of my spare time studying coding patterns, best practices and new technologies, my efforts in work improved across the board. My pace was higher than ever, my communication with other engineers was noticeable, my suggestions were accepted with open arms. My manager was greatful to note my improvement and fealt I was ready for a major feature.

weeks later = I completed my assigned work well ahead of schedule. My work flew through testing and came back with minimal suggestions from peer review.

One area that interests me in the field of skill-learning is the relevance of age. Professionals in the vast majority of activities started training at a very young age, usually 5-8. It is only in skills that are not typically accessible to kids, like poker, that the starting age is later. I've heard that this has to do with the natural malleability of a child's mind and the absence of bad habits, as well as the relative freedom that children have with their time. 
Whatever the case, it can be demoralizing to adult beginners/casual amateurs when they see the depth of skill that many young prodigies possess. To take tennis and chess as examples, it is exceedingly rare that any elite player started learning those games after the age of 10. Even adult beginners who abandon all outside distractions (like work and personal lives) will not reach that elite level.

The list is basically what an AI algorithm does.
1. valid environment (devs create environment that is deterministic and repeats for AI to train)
2. many repetitions (billions of tests per second)
3. timely feedback (each tests gives a fit score which is a feedback on how it performed and adjust accordingly to make that score higher)
4. deliberate practice ("getting comfortable" devs call this overfitting, unable to learn new things and stuck in the local minima, to fix this you need to randomize training samples or "deliberate practice")

"Don't get comfortable" is a lesson I'd like to drive home by this statistic: some 70-90% of accidental finger amputations happen at 2 ages, 16 and 60. All the time in between those ages is marked by remarkably safe individuals who go their entire career without a single incident. Before and after those ages is when nearly every finger is removed via any means. Below 16, the reasons are typically doors, mowers, and knives. After 60, the reasons are power tools, typically the sort of hand tool an individual would've used for his entire career, probably without incident.

Personally, my finger was removed at 16, following an exceptionally poor night of sleep, followed by a very late arrival at work, where I needed to do about 2 days' worth of catch up work, with a poorly maintained chopsaw (miter saw), in an environment with a poor (but improving) attitude towards safety. That chopsaw removed my finger about 2 hours after starting work, and I became part of that aforementioned statistic.

I'm no investment expert, so take anything I say on the subject with a giant pinch of salt. But: I am surprised by the claim that hedge funds are supposed to outperform the market. That's not my understanding at all. It's right there in the name, hedge funds are about hedging your bets. My understanding is that hedge funds are for investors who can't afford to lose too much in the short term. You accept lower returns in the good times and a lower overall long term return in exchange for smaller losses in the bad times. This is useful if, for example, you're retiring. You might not live to see the returns on a long term investment, and you need at least some of the funds in the short term so heavy short-term losses aren't acceptable. So you put your money into a hedge fund to protect it against inflation while also keeping short-term losses to a minimum.
From this point of view, the basket of hedge funds seems to me to be doing pretty well. From the same point of view I'm utterly bemused that a professional investor would bet a basket of hedge funds against Warren Buffet. Have I got this totally wrong?

Let's look at situations where this isn't true.
Cybersecurity experts aren't likely to get repeated experiments with feedback. Each task they receive usually takes days if not weeks to process. Additionally, cybersecurity threats are one off events, usually involving an incredibly specific exploit which is patched immediately after the threat is addressed. Pen testing can help with some of these issues, but does not resolve them altogether.
Atheletes get all 4 features. Yet even with all 4 qualifications and 10000 hours, being an expert as an athlete is highly dependent on your genetics.
Artists get all 4 features. Yet it is pretty questionable if we have an expert class of painters like we do chess players or physicists. In fact, people are unable to distinguish whether modern art is done by famous artists or amateurs most of the time (or even schoolchildren in some cases)
There are definitely expert writers and authors. However the feedback for writing books is especially delayed, and there are not many repetitions. There are expert authors who have only written a few books. And it is rare that authors will push out of their comfort zone by "practice writing" difficult books.

This is misleading and loaded with concealed assumptions. It is not the case that expert knowledge involves prediction. Rather, complex phenomenon are appropriately interpreted, explained, and deconstructed. Repetition suggests a narrow subject focus on an object that follows predictable laws that can be decoded. Yet social and political life are non-rational, and irreducible. Often the observer must constitute reality and define it before applying casual inference. Which is why environment is suggested as a criteria, but all topics are contextualized by relations of power that determine the winners, and reveal the meaning. Nothing human is ever random, because random itself is the result of intentionality at some point, with some purpose. This also misjudges the concept of expertise, which is not only a practice, but a social role, usually one done for the benefit of others. It is not accuracy, but public responsibility that matter. Just as priests do not describe reality but spirit, and philosophers do not seek to explain but understand, so experts are knowledge guides who contribute to the public good through focused effort of learning, teaching, and finally, offering the rest of us their critical judgement on criteria of relevance. Expertise is a form of democratic citizenship in which effort of the appropriate quantity of hours validates their judgement for others.

This reminds me of Car insurance.  Why does car insurance cost more the more miles you drive per year?  If you drive less than a few thousands of miles per year, you get a massive discount on insurance, yet in Aviation, if you insure a private airplane, they give you discounts based on how many hours of flight time you have in that type of aircraft.  It's exactly the opposite of expertise based risk.  If you were having open heart surgery, would you want the 20 years of experience heart surgeon or the med student with no basic experience ever?  Obviously the expert.  Unfortunately though, car insurance rewards the non-expert drivers, and the expert drivers pay a penalty - even as they avoid more accidents driving way more miles.  This is a fraud/scam/unjust racket based on nothing less than market influence and price discrimination, not anything at all tied to risk.  If this were really based on risk, we should be seeing how they've calculated the risk - and how the expert drivers save the insurance agencies so much money they would go broke without us.

I think the "thousands of hours of practice + timely feedback" is slightly misleading, because it's really about the type of practice and feedback that really matters.

You could play tens of thousands of hours of chess games and never really improve, because you'd just do the same thing over and over again on autopilot. You think you're "practicing", but you're really not. Same thing with e.g. golf, you might spend thousands of hours hitting thousands and thousands of balls on the driving range, but if you're practicing "the wrong thing", you won't actually improve - your swing might actually just get worse as you'll learn the wrong thing (meaning that a coach will first have to help you unlearn the bad patterns that you taught yourself). Instead, a few hours of correct practice with a coach helping you focus on the right thing will take you much further than the thousands of hours of "practice" on your own.

For timely feedback too, you might think that winning or losing the game is providing you with timely feedback, but it's really not, it actually doesn't matter. You would need to evaluate the game with a chess engine after the game (or with a coach to help you analyze), to get the real feedback of where you made mistakes. The same thing with golf to some extent, most people are really really focused on where the ball is going, and using that as the feedback mechanism, but for actual improvement and learning the most important part is your body and club movement, which you would need e.g. video analysis to know.

So yes, you do need thousands of hours and practice + timely feedback, but if you do the wrong type of practice or use the "wrong" feedback, you probably won't improve anyway.

As someone that LOVES to learn new things and wants to get good at those things, I can confirm this is pretty much how it works. Over the years, I've learned piano, sign language, Rubik's cubes, chess, and recently, been trying to get good at the game rocket league. Over time I've kinda recognized the things that helped me learn, and what makes me get better at those things, and a lot of it is all the same thing.
With Rubik's cubes, it'll all about recognizing cases by chunking, getting algorithms into your muscle memory, recognition speed, and being able to not look at the current thing you're doing so you can have less pauses.
With chess, it's about remembering openings, mid game, and the endings. Learning many different openings, helps you think less, and then you get to look at the board as a whole instead of looking at 1 move at a time.
And literally everything else.... it's all about recognition; getting familiar with patterns and being able to just remember what to do in those situations is key to getting better.

Hi, long time follower here! I liked the video.
While I understand the point you are making in this video I would like to point out some stuff that bothers me a little.
First, the definition of being expert at something has to be defined precisely beforehand. In this video it seems like you defined an expert as someone that can predict outcomes more accurately than the average given that the problem is in their field. Which is OK for the sake of the video but still disregards the added value pure knowledge and sorted information can have on their own.
Second, when comparing a tennis player ball control and a prediction of future events is unfair. What could be comparable is a tennis player predicting the outcome of a match beforehand VS predicting how a student is going to be doing. To me, the most important thing you mentioned is the quantity of variables involved. I think what makes an expert has more to do with the number of variables one can deal with while staying accurate and less about the accuracy of predictions with too many variables. The success rate a pro tennis player has when predicting the outcome of a match after looking only at the shoes the players are wearing and the kind of rackets they have has nothing to do with his expertise in the field. It would not surprise me if, given a problem with a set number of variables, all experts had similar results regardless of the field.
So what I want to say is that while I think I get what you're saying, the way it is presented make it seem that in some areas there can be no expert and thus invalidating any expert input in high variable contexts. While true to some extent the way of phrasing it can be harmful today. In a world where climate change and health hazards exists, should we dismiss climatologists and health specialists when they are working in high variable environments? These people cannot predict accurately the future but does that make their input worthless? Are they not to be called experts because of that? As unpredictable the future is, an epidemiologist telling to wear a mask (low variables) should be listened to even if when predicting the state of an outbreak her/his opinion should be considered in a more critical manner.

Why it's hard for many people to become an expert:
1. Many repeated attempts: It can get boring doing the same thing over and over again or disappointing when progress isn't being made.
2. Valid environment: There are many instances where one cannot predict an outcome due to lack of feedback and/or time.
3. Timely Feedback: Like the environment, sometimes feedback is lagging or unavailable.
4. Deliberate Practice: It can be boring and/or difficult to focus all the energy on a single activity.

So even if one repeats many attempts with deliberate practice it still takes more than that to become an expert. They can be consciously thinking about what they're doing and repeat it many times, but if they're just making the same mistakes and not knowing it, due to unavailability of feedback or a somewhat predictable environment, then progress might not even be made.

Kind of a scary thought, but we still need to try.

There are more problems with predictions though. An expert might be able to correctly identify possible problems and possible solutions, but what happens is often more complex. For example: Marx correctly analyzed that workers were in an untenable position and he correctly (probably) predicted that if nothing would change, people might rise up.
What he didn't predict was that we got unions, that gave workers a bit of power back, completely changing everything he was thinking about.

In other words: predicting the future is really not feasible. You can identify problems and even think up possible scenarios, but there will always be factors you didn't think about.

If immediate feedback is this important, wouldn’t this mean that the best way to practice chess is by starting with endgames? That way you don’t have to wait 30-70 turns to get feedback. If you just practice the last few moves, you get faster feedback. Then, you can move on to practicing midgames. Now you can evaluate your midgame play on the basis of the endgame scenarios you create, rather than having to finish the whole game. Because you already know endgames, your feedback on midgames can now come faster as well. After midgames, you can eventually apply this to early game play, to set up optimal midgame scenarios which set up optimal endgame scenarios.

100% this is how I was trained to be a ballet dancer and I didn't even recognize it. We do the same movements in slightly varying patterns every single day in a structured class, and for actual repertoire we repeat the EXACT same movements over and over, with a teacher or coach telling you what to improve after each attempt. As you get stronger, you do more and more challenging combinations of movement with increased complexity and strength requirements, and you spend more time reviewing and conditioning on your own time. Eventually you get really good at learning and doing choreography in certain styles/from certain choreographers because you start to recognize the patterns of movement they tend to employ.

3:24 This part is definitly untrue. I've seen chessmasters being for example able to play through a long series of move in their heads to determine whether that is the correct move. So long and complicated that not only would most people be unable to get the ideas for those moves, but they are simply unable to generate the pictures of these positions in their head. Another example is chessmasters being able to play multiple opponents blindfolded at the same time. I would not even be able to remember my own pieces postion on a a single board after just a couple of move. No normal human can play 10 people, without seeing the boards and win, no way. Those skills may not be related to IQ, but they are certainly something more then recognizing patterns or chess positions.
You can't just remember the positions all throughout the games, you have to rigorously check most relevant moves as small details in the position which has not occured before may make the whole difference. Not only that but you have to understand the position, not just remeber what happened in previous game, since each position holds an almost endless number of variations.

No matter how many games I played, how strong my memory was i would still not be nearly as quick witted, stragetic and least of all as good at visualizing the board as a chess master. Despite having played many chess games, when playing through more that 5 moves ahead in my mind I will easily get lost unless it is forced moves and will easily miss important detaiils, not because of my lack of understanding but simply because i cannot make the mental picture and check the position carefully.

If we follow the news today, we see a world about to collapse, as if we were experiencing the worst time ever. Therefore, we are able to believe that our grandparents were right, longing for "the good old days."
Grim indicators abound–extreme heat waves and raging fires in Europe and the United States, America bleeding between one mass shooting and the next, inflation reaching historic highs to the point that recession seems likely, the unending Russian war in Ukraine continuing to cause shockwaves across the globe.
Britain and Italy face political instability. Sri Lanka sank in front of people's eyes while its leaders fled the country. The quiet country of Japan saw the assassination of its former prime minister in the daylight.
As shocking as everything looks, nothing has changed that much in the world. The main change has been in the accumulation of information and people's connections in the world. In past times we set out on walking tours to hear what was going on in the neighboring town and rocked inside a ship for two months to get to know a distant country.
In later periods, we bought a ticket for a high-speed train or took planes to land on a distant continent to know other realities and people. Now without getting up from the chair and with the press of a key we are there, in the heart of the world. In less than a second, the entire colorful, noisy and bustling reality unfolds before us, stunning us with its growing influence.
We hear and see, feel, admire and respond to everything that happens to everyone in every corner in real time. Communication between us requires us to absorb an intensive flow of information which we consume like addicts.
How often does someone read a book and go to a friend to share, "Listen, what a good book I read!” We are in a world that is all news that we are not built to absorb, engagements that we are unable to tolerate. As a consequence, people are getting sicker physically and mentally.
The endless bonds formed between us are cold, flat and alienated. They have no depth, warmth or identification. They lack sympathy and willingness to approach, and do not take into account that we are one. If the world seems full of crises, it is the ties between us that are broken.
The physical bonds between us have become tight and fast, and so it should be, but we need to adjust ourselves internally and emotionally to it. We need to insert warmth within these bonds that will strengthen and connect us instead of breaking us apart. You can turn off the news a bit, open a purposeful book, talk to each other, and feel each other.
Instead of running around with eyes on the monitor and absorbing fragmented pieces of information, we can get a real picture of reality when we look at creation as integral, knowing that it has direction and purpose. All of reality, past or present has a single purpose: to make us perceive that we are one, like nature, and to understand that only through our mutual guarantee and interdependence will we be able to overcome any hardship. When we achieve this perspective, the perception of the world that we see will finally come into a beautiful balance called peace.

Interesting to think about this in the context of my own field: Computer Science. Especially when writing code, it does illuminate some things for me. I work with a lot of scientist from other fields who mostly write software as a tool for expressing ideas from their respective fields. Most of them have had little to no formal training in writing code before starting to work. What I notice is that these people fairly easy learn how to avoid bugs and write code that executes, but are terrible at preventing structural issues (e.g. does this software scale easily or how easy is it to add new functionality in the future). The timely feedback issue seems crititcal here. When trying to write code that executes, the feedback is almost immediate: The software returns an error on running or it doesn't. The structural problems however aren't evaluated by any immediate system or even at all (especially for people who's main area of expertise is actually not software).

Great video Derek. As always! I was reminded when you talked about system 1 & system 2 of something I learned decades ago in sales, although this applies to pretty well any endeavour you choose to learn & master. Long version short: there are 4 different components to how to learn. There is competence level (incompetent or competent) and conscious level (conscious or unconscious). As you started learning a new skill, you were considered unconscious incompetent - you didn't know what you needed to know & were unaware of that combined with being largely incompetent at it. As you got better, you moved up to conscious incompetent (where you now understand that you didn't know what to do and you were still incompetent at doing it). Then you could move up another level to concious competent (at this point, you're good at something BUT you have to still focus hard to do the task) and then finally, the ultimate level is unconscious competent (which is where you are so good AND practiced at the task you don't need to think and devote all your brain power to do it AND you're also competent at it). The goal in sales training was to become so good at it that it was an unconscious/effortless skill that you were successful at.

Steps to produce expert results:
1) 10,000 hours of practicing deliberately where you get timely feedback
2) The medium you are practicing in is predictable with the factors you can perceive

More specifically:
1) Many repeated attempts to develop recognition
2) Valid environment - predictability (you are able to see enough of the relevant factors to have confidence of an outcome)
3) Direct feedback about your decision making in a timely manner s.t. you can extract the consequences of specific actions
4) Consciously practicing, not going on "autopilot" and coasting along once you understand enough.

How this could be applied to becoming a programming expert:
1. Repeated Experience with feedback: Solve lots of practical programming problems. If possible get feedback from an expert. Thought from myself: Those should require skills for all difficulty/expertise levels and near to real world problems (require the skills an expert has).
2. Valid Environment: Should be given in programming, as it is most of the time deterministic.
3. Timely Feedback: Not given everytime -> bugs are possible. Emphasizes the importance of writing or having automated tests.
4. Deliberate Practice/Don't get to comfortable: Use the 10,000 hours to challenge yourself at the edge of your ability, doing stuff you're not good at (yet) with full focus.

The thing about most masters in chess.

They don't know how to play chess. They recognize the moves, and know the next optimal move.

Masters typically have between 12, and 20 moves in advance stored.

However, when say, a beginner suicides a piece in a non-optimal move, but not in a directly wrong movement

I.E. sacrificing a rook and a pawn for a rook on the other board, suddenly the lack of recognition comes crashing down, and it becomes difficult to rally the board to one sides advantage.

It's how I as a casual, beat someone who was not a casual, and been playing chess for 20+ years.

Sadly, at a certain point could can force the board into this recognizable state.

It's one of the problems of the chess scene. Rote memorization kills creativity.

100% this is how I was trained to be a ballet dancer and I didn't even recognize it. We do the same movements in slightly varying patterns every single day in a structured class, and for actual repertoire we repeat the EXACT same movements over and over, with a teacher or coach telling you what to improve after each attempt. As you get stronger, you do more and more challenging combinations of movement with increased complexity and strength requirements, and you spend more time reviewing and conditioning on your own time. Eventually you get really good at learning and doing choreography in certain styles/from certain choreographers because you start to recognize the patterns of movement they tend to employ.

10K hours not enough to be expert, you also need:
1. Many repeated attempts with feedback (experts in their area who don't get feedback tend to do worse than random chance even if they have sent their life on that subject)
2. valid environment - regularities that make it somewhat predictable (chess boards, basketball courts); experts have difficulty to predict one offs or random scenarios
3. timely feedback - immediate feedback more important than delayed feedback
4. deliberate practice - you have to repeatedly attempt things that you aren't good at, you need to challenge yourself; if you play the same song on a guitar you won't improve. Not just hours of playing, but how many hours of serious playing

The stock market example is a bit iffy. These analysts try their best to reflect all available information in the price of a stock. If they do that correctly, only new information (which is by it's very nature unpredictable) will allow you to beat the market. So the fact that they do no better than a dart-throwing monkey is actually a testament to their collective skill. Measuring their expert-ness by their collective returns is a bit like rating farmers on the price of the crops, rather then the size of the harvest. If farmers all farm well, the price will actually fall! This does not however mean that they are not good farmers. Actually quite the opposite. And the same goes for financial analysts. If they are experts and do their job really well, returns are random and their predictions worthless, which is exactly what we see.

Going back to the stocks example, I think funnily enough, this video kind of explains why most people fail in the markets. They haven't developed a rules based strategy that they have spent hours upon hours, gaining feedback on how it works and its effectiveness in the markets, and when it comes time for execution, instead of sticking to the strategy (like the mouse) they tend to play around or "wing it" and end up performing way worse than they would have otherwise.

Also with trading/investing, there are plenty of other factors like limited resources (money and time) that people don't have much to spend, which is not enough for them to gain timely feedback or the knowledge necessary to even get good at a strategy and understand the market they wish to invest/trade in. The markets are also unpredictable/volatile at certain times of the day or when certain news events take place which may make it harder to gather data (since it's another factor to consider).

That's why the failure rate is so high. So if a retail trader/investor wants to improve their chances in the market, they should perform hours of mock executions (over the course of months) and preferably have a mentor in the field with years of experience so that they can learn from their mistakes before ever deciding to use live funds.

This isn't financial advice though, it's but an observation.

I call it the Math prof fallacy:
"By copying things from the blackboard one memorises better." No, you spend time copying things symbol by symbol and you are >10s back because you cannot see what the professor is currently writing as he stands before it. So you copy things out of context from what the professor is currently saying and if you lack understanding as is often the case with new subjects or in the first few semesters you cannot predict what symbol comes next. My personal favourites are proving stuff with the greek letter "XI" with 4 instances (indices) multiplied in a random fashion without seeing any sense of what someone is doing. Practice doesn't make perfect - directed practice with proper feedback makes perfect.
You can bang away for 16 hours a day on the piano in your living room for 50 years straight, and still not get anywhere close to becoming a virtuoso.
Unless you receive specific feedback on what you're doing wrong, you have litlte chance to improve much.

You do need to practice enough for this feedback to materialize though.
A beginner makes so many random errors that it's impossible to discern a PATTERN behind their errors.
Only once you improve, these error patterns emerge, which allows to take corrective action, because you attack this pattern.

The deficiencies of your skills start taking some non-random shape (that can be addressed).
You can only tackle your weakness if it's repetitive in some way.

The hardest disciplines are those where the feedback loop is very big, so feedback comes with an inherent delay.
One example would be life itself.
You don't get immediate feedback on (most) bad life choices like you would when you play table tennis.

It reminds me of what Lasker (the 2nd world chess champion in history) said about chess: ""on the chessboard lies and hypocrisy do not survive long".
That's the key point. If you make mistakes in chess, they'll be punished soon.

Not quite the case when it comes to the investment market, for instance.
Often there is no immediate punishment for "lies and hypocrisy". That's how bubbles (like the infamous housing bubbles) form. The wheels turn slowly and by the time your negative feedback forms (which can take years), it becomes a catastrophe. It's too late to take proper corrective action at this point. You still do learn (kind of), but the pace is lower and the cost of the practice much higher.

I feel like the way you describe the stock market as "low validity" is rather inaccurate. The stock (and other markets) have the highest noise (lowest validity) across the shortest time periods (1 minute, 1 second), but diverge more into other factors such as psychological for longer time periods (1 week, 1 month, 1year...). Additionally, new variables are constantly introduced into the market, so even if you're looking at the minute-by-minute noise - at any moment a potential external factor might come into the mix and, if you were aware of what the factor is, you'd be able to profit off of that - and "deliberate practice" comes into play here as you get better at recognizing these factors.

The reason the hedge funds underperformed VS. the market is the fact that it was the performance of a whole bunch of funds, averaged out. Many of them will make critical mistakes, make exceptionally bad trades, and bring the collective average down. If the person betting against buffet was able to pick the hedge fund(s) that outperformed, then they would've won the bet. "Picking the winners" is not low validity either, as long as you have at least some idea of what the funds will be doing.

comment_text: The pattern recognition became very clear to me when I learned Morse code. The human brain takes 50 milliseconds to process and understand a sound. People regularly send and receive Morse code at 30 words per minute, which puts the dit character and the gap between all characters at 40 milliseconds. So you literally have to process sounds faster than the brain can recognize them. Over time you start to hear whole words in the code rather than individual letters, but you still have to decode call signs character by character. You basically cache the sounds in your brain without processing them, and once the whole set of characters passes, your brain is able to turn it into an idea and add it to the stack of previous ideas while your ears are already caching the next set of characters.

These four things actually made me think of what's required for AI to learn something

1. Repeated Attempts with feedback:
This represents the data you've got and its labels, or alternatively actual attempts and rewards in the case of reinforcement learning. Examples are AI "attempting" to classify images of dogs/cats and being told it's right or wrong. For RL it could be a chess playing AI playing a match and receiving feedback in the form of winning or losing.

2. Valid Environment:
Like illustrated for humans in the video, if the environment is random, AI won't end up learning anything. However in the button example, unlike the human, and much like the rat, the AI should converge to only choosing the green button. If the input to the AI is the same for each attempt this convergence should happen pretty much immediately. If the input is completely random the AI will still attempt to find patterns like the human, but I believe it should still converge to only the choice with the highest probability.

3. Timely Feedback:
This one isn't super relevant to supervised learning since it's assumed the data is provided with labels, no matter how timely those labels/feedback were given in the data gathering stage. For example, if you're using AI to predict grades of students based on their past grades, you won't wait for current students to get their grades; you'd simply train on past data that already includes the feedback (which I guess is also possible for humans actually).
Timely feedback is more relevant to reinforcement learning. That's why RL training is often done in simulations instead of the real world: to speed up feedback (and also to limit actual real world damage in some cases, like in robotics or self-driving). An example of this sped up feedback is the famous AlphaStar playing a custom version of the StarCraft game, where instead of waiting for the standard game in real time, it was able to play something crazy like 400 years overnight.
However, this is actually just learning faster. The AI would learn just as well if it didn't have timely feedback, just slower. For humans I guess the problem is that we might forget our thought process and decision by the time the feedback arrives, because our minds are occupied with other things and not focused on a single goal.

4. Deliberate Practice / Don't get too comfortable:
Indeed if AI comes across certain rare examples, and then keeps training afterwards without seeing similar examples again, it can end up "forgetting". This happens because the model is continuously optimized for the most recent batch of examples (in mini-batch gradient decent at least), which means at every nudge of its parameters it does not care at all about previous batches. The reason this works is because the batches have patterns in common, and therefore the model will learn these common patterns, and gradually forget anything that doesn't line up with these patterns. This is a feature, not a bug; if it learned everything, instead of just the patterns, that's simply memorization, which doesn't generalize to new examples not included in the data.

comment_text: The pattern recognition became very clear to me when I learned Morse code. The human brain takes 50 milliseconds to process and understand a sound. People regularly send and receive Morse code at 30 words per minute, which puts the dit character and the gap between all characters at 40 milliseconds. So you literally have to process sounds faster than the brain can recognize them. Over time you start to hear whole words in the code rather than individual letters, but you still have to decode call signs character by character. You basically cache the sounds in your brain without processing them, and once the whole set of characters passes, your brain is able to turn it into an idea and add it to the stack of previous ideas while your ears are already caching the next set of characters.

100% this is how I was trained to be a ballet dancer and I didn't even recognize it. We do the same movements in slightly varying patterns every single day in a structured class, and for actual repertoire we repeat the EXACT same movements over and over, with a teacher or coach telling you what to improve after each attempt. As you get stronger, you do more and more challenging combinations of movement with increased complexity and strength requirements, and you spend more time reviewing and conditioning on your own time. I am a high school teacher. i tis common knowledge and practice in teaching that you become a better teacher through experience. Those that encounter a larger variety of situations and experineces tend to perform better in a larger variety of situations.

Personally I have seen a teacher perform poorly at a school because they had onyl had expereince in schools that had well behaved students. Despite many years expereince in teaching, they lacked that expereince. but becasue they were a teacher, and supported by teachers that understood the value of expeiereice it took only 3 months for them to adjust their teaching behaviour to the new type of students, ones that cared more about relationships than personal academic success.

This is where some experts rely not on skill, but on adaption. A skilled teacher does not rely on their individual skill to deal with a specific situation, becasue almost every student is different. Rather they rely on the ability to assess and adapt to a new student quickly.
We assess a student, seek information from our fellow teachers who may have experience, disseminate this information, adjust it to our personal methods, experiment in class, and adapt as necassary.

A chessmaster is like an AI, they are replacable by a computer. A teacher, however, is doing something far more complex in how they work. Replacing a teacher with an AI is far more difficult. When you can replace a teacher with AI, you likely have generated true intelligence.

What you fail to mention is that there is a difference between learning information and actively using it. Being able to think fast or having a lot of memorized information are useless by themselves unless you know how to best apply it. Empirical feedback (from experience) does not teach us underlying causes, only statistical and probabilistic variables. To UNDERSTAND, one must know first-causes and principles, which aren't discernable from information and experience by themselves. One has to not only think about 'the what' but also 'the why', which forms into abstract principles which can be applied across many fields and mental categories. The tautology "all bachelors are unmarried" is one example. We need not go around the world to find every bachelor to confirm its validity. Similarly, when making complex predictions on the world market or politics, so called 'experts' simply do not understand the underlying principles enough to think about what they cannot directly see, yet this is what they've understood to be adequate. A degree at any level will not teach you this. It is entirely up to the individual to assess and control the quality of their thinking, as educational institutions possibly can't since they are largely based on the same feedback that errs professionals when out of school.

I think the problem here is with the definition of expert. The label is applied way too broadly without acknowledgement of obvious distinction.

Someone who studies a field for 10,000 hours isn't the same as someone who practices in that same field for 10,000 hours. They are experts at two different things.

One is an expert at study with that field as a subject while the other is the actual expert in the field.

Chess expert (peak elo was officially only 1863, but I played at a fairly consistent 2000+ level before FIDE ratings became ubiquitous) and former professional money manager here: the stock market is a perfectly valid testing environment over longer time periods, however between fund mandates, the need to convince colleagues of your ideas, and pressure to maintain funds under management, it is almost impossible to invest effectively in a professional environment.

For context: the money I managed professionally delivered more or less benchmark market returns, while my family's private retirement savings fund is up by around 1400% in seventeen years (that's around 16.8% per annum) these returns happened concurrently, and along the way I lost count of the number of things I did with the family money that would have resulted in me losing my job if I'd done the same thing with client money.

By the way one reason that hedge funds often return below the market is that they are not trying to make money off the market. They are trying to create uncorrelated returns (whether uncorrelated returns actually exist is another question). These are returns that will not be as greatly affected by the market, so less extreme lows and highs. With the general market trend being expansion it would be expected for funds to not perform as well as the market as they have lower highs (but also higher lows as was shown in the graph during 2008). A good way to think of it is that hedge funds are not a way for the rich to get richer, but a way to stay rich.

I believe your analogy about single stock over index is flawed and ignores fundamental market facts.

Let's take the 2020 oil crash for an example;
There's a few fundamental undeniable facts that are at play.
1. Oil will not stopped being used overnight.
2. The world is extremely dependant on it.


these fundamental facts can, in an investors eyes, be an excellent reason to buy shares of oil companies who's stocks are in freefall and not the Indices (or both).
There is a far more likely chance that those failing companies will rebound along with the various Oil/Energy Indices, but by having a pie of shares in a handful of individual shares will also have the potential to profit off the spike of a single stock that the averaging nature of a index will lessen.
Of course, there is the risk that the oil industry collapses, though realistically and pragmatically thinking to would not do it overnight, and having too much oil and not much use because of a pandemic is hardly a reason, it's hard to see how it would not recover, but, yes the risk was there.

Just because an averaged index over a long period means good and profitable returns does not exclusively make the opposite bad and unprofitable, It's just makes it more risky.
There is only one thing an investor has control over is the level of risk they take and what they do to minimize losses if the risk is proven wrong, there's far more one can do than buy or sell a share, there are plenty of ways to hedge and lessen potential drastic losses to not much.
Humans, are lazy & emotional people, every investor at some point has made a catastrophic accident and has refused to damage control before too much is lost, it is a rite of passage. Unfortunately this behavior still exists in professional investment firms, it may not even be the trader, it may be unrealistic quotas forcing them to mismanage risk.
Point being, there are too many variables to exclusively say index is better than shares and the argument is a bit in bad faith as the argument posed is averages always win, and while this is true on average it's no reason to creatively manage risk over different periods of time in order to minimize losses and maximize potential.

"Chess positions that could occur in a real game". That phrase is almost always overlooked when calculating how many positions are possible in a chess game. The number of "Possible" board states is summed up by a brute force calculation that includes literal millions upon millions of positions that are actually impossible to achieve in a real game.
I personally normally think 150 moves ahead in a chess game.
Meaning i know what a good endgame is and know how to force those positions over board, before any game even starts. The fact is most real games are less than 40 moves apiece. That make the real possible positions in a REAL game closer to 5,000.
I base that number on the amount of games listed in the annual chess game compendium.
I forget the name of that. My bad)
I just wish that whenever anyone cites the "Possible" positions they subtract the illegal positions from that number. Example: How many of those positions include positions with 2 pawns on the farthest row?
Add another fact of the game: Of all; the possible positions there are, most openings fold into the same position over the board.
The term for this is "Transposition".
There is a simple reason for this omission in the usual conversation. The math needed to eliminate the illegal positions is (to say the least) hugely more complex than simply multiplying the pieces by the number of squares.
In conclusion the number is (in practice) at most way under a thousandth of the number generally given as the "possible" number of chess positions.

I'm wondering if anyone else sees this video as being rather naive or short sighted. It seems entirely reasonable to say that we "shouldn't trust experts" in fields where there isn't 1. repeated attempts with feedback, 2. environment validity, and 3. timely feedback (the 4th point is seemingly obviously true), but this line of reasoning seems to have large gaps in normal considerations of "mastery" or "expertise" and how one would get to such a level. For example, a master composer, who might reasonably be considered a master because their novel compositions deeply reached millions, would not particularly learn to compose by writing 1000 pieces while receiving timely and valid feedback on each one (music doesn't particularly have "valid feedback" anyways). Nonetheless, said master composer could absolutely learn from other methods, like listening to lots of music while trying to hear different music patterns, or experimenting on their own with only "self-feedback", or attempting to "understand" other peoples music, or learning to "find their own niche", etc. (all of which lack the first 3 criteria where the video seem to strongly suggests that even missing just 1 immediately invalidates the practice).

This kind of "reductionist" viewpoint (of seeing humans as basically just "machine learning models" that need lots of data and feedback in a valid environment) may be true to some extent, but is clearly not the end-all-be-all of expertise or mastery, which for the most part is more of an open question in cognitive and computational learning research. I say this all to provide constructive feedback to the Veritasium team who's goal is seemingly to illuminate "truth" and not biased narratives. Though maybe I'm wrong, so please provide me feedback on this comment ;)

comment_text: The pattern recognition became very clear to me when I learned Morse code. The human brain takes 50 milliseconds to process and understand a sound. People regularly send and receive Morse code at 30 words per minute, which puts the dit character and the gap between all characters at 40 milliseconds. So you literally have to process sounds faster than the brain can recognize them. Over time you start to hear whole words in the code rather than individual letters, but you still have to decode call signs character by character. You basically cache the sounds in your brain without processing them, and once the whole set of characters passes, your brain is able to turn it into an idea and add it to the stack of previous ideas while your ears are already caching the next set of characters.

Thanks for another great video. I have to take exception to a conclusion you drew about radiologists and mammography. The overall miss rate for breast cancer on screening mammography (pts without palpable lumps, etc.), is actually about 1 in 8, 12.5%. Not the 30 % implied. There was a study years ago which may have misled your reasearch. That study found that 70 odd percent of breast cancers could be identified on prior imaging, but that does not mean that the all findings necessarily represented cancer at the time of prior imaging. As an aside for those who may wonder why - If all potential findings on every mammogram were worked up with additional views the overall radiation exposure in the patient population would become unreasonable and the cost would be prohibitive.
The suggestion that the high miss rate (obviously, even 12.5 %, is far from ideal) is due to lack of feedback is interesting. Radiologists do get feedback on their performance both in terms of overall stats like cancer detection rate and, to an imperfect extent on individual cases. I think it is that feedback, combined with continuing ed that allows more experienced radiologists to read with greater confidence and usually fewer additional view mammograms than more recently trained docs. In my experience the less experienced docs request more additional views but their cancer detection rate seems quite comparable to experienced docs.

I've noticed a possible problem with the rat study. The rat was subject to Pavlovian conditioning, whereas the human likely wasn't (for ethical reasons). Even if the human was receiving a 'reward' and 'punishment' of some kind, say; a piece of chocolate and a mild electric shock. It's still not the same as what the rat received because 'food' in general means more to a rat as they are more primitive/less complex animals with active food seeking hardwired to a degree separate to how it is for humans as our increased intelligence allows not only for less food insecurity (especially in the west) but inventive ways of changing and adapting our palate. A rat's palate is generally the same across the world. Humans' palates, however, vary widely. And even a mild electric shock is likely not so 'mild' to a rat, as they are a smaller and weaker animal.
These differences in rats and humans matter greatly with such a study as they are designed to measure differences. Or, at the very least, claim to spot one i.e. humans' penchant for change. Which, for the rat, is absent according to this study.
If the study for rats and humans doesn't match in relation to their species-specific differences, then is it not flawed?

This is a nice video, but it misses the point of hedge funds. It's in the name: Hedge. Hedge funds are supposed to reduce risk, not maximize return. That's why mixtures like 60% stocks, 40% bonds are considered reasonable portfolios. It's no surprise that most hedge funds outperform the market in bear markets and underperform in bull markets since most hedge funds are less risky than a random collection of stocks. It is a common misconception that the only goal is to maximize return, so I guess this communicates well with people who don't understand investments, but I think you can avoid this type of inaccuracy.

I think the ideal pattern is more like a tree shape ... some good depth, and a lot of breadth.

Anand - Zapata is a very famous game because it’s effectively a joke or meme within the high level chess community - Anand (at the time arguably the best player in the world) lost a piece in 6 moves. Howell (the presenter) showed (his friend and colleague) Magnus an opening he’s probably laughed at many many times. Most strong chess players would recognise Anand - Zapata after Nc3, because the Nc3 line is no longer common at the top level, and Nc3 Bf5 Qe2 is something of a running joke within chess circles from this position, because the WCC lost in 6 moves.

(2) The person requires parents, teachers and tutors who provide undeniable support - financial, personal care, honest feedback, etc.  (3) The audience of the expert must show a direct interest in the actions.  (4) Given the enthusiasm of the trade/craft, the person must be a 'quick study' - to easily absorb the tasks, etc.  (5) The person typically blend into the history and culture at the time.  Mastering the music of 1950 would not be so developed and responsive today.  And (6) it takes time - deep immersion for about 10 years of persistent effort. #4: Don't be comfortable.

This instantly reminded me of H Day in Sweden, the day when everyone switched driving from the left to the right side of the roadways. Many people were certain that it would cause untold deaths and many more accidents. In fact, for many years afterward, accident rates plummeted. The assumption is that people were suddenly paying much closer attention to how they drive. Having driven on the opposite side of the road in another country, I'm sure that it also made driving fairly stressful, but that seems like a fair price to pay for fewer injuries and deaths caused by lazy, comfortable driving habits. #4 is a great, general lesson.

The whole event is rather fascinating. If you're curious to learn more about it, there's a great, short episode by the podcast "99% Invisible" that's worth checking out. It's episode 215, titled "H-Day."

Something else that goes along with the route to becoming an expert are the 4 stages of learning.
1. Unconscious Incompetence, you're bad but aren't aware of exactly how bad you are because you know very little of the skill or subject you're practicing.
2. Conscious Incompetence, you have a better grasp on the subject knowledge and its depths after putting in a good amount of time and practice but you're not quite good at it yet.
3. Conscious Competence, you've put in enough time and effort with enough feedback that you're now good at what you're doing but it's a conscious effort and you'll screw up if you aren't concentrating enough.
4. Unconscious Competence, you've practiced long enough and put in so much time and effort that you can perform the skill or talk about the subject as easy as walking, you may dip into Conscious Competence if you encounter an infrequent occurrence in your skill or subject but you've got what it takes to get through it

Something else that goes along with the route to becoming an expert are the 4 stages of learning.
1. Unconscious Incompetence, you're bad but aren't aware of exactly how bad you are because you know very little of the skill or subject you're practicing.
2. Conscious Incompetence, you have a better grasp on the subject knowledge and its depths after putting in a good amount of time and practice but you're not quite good at it yet.
3. Conscious Competence, you've put in enough time and effort with enough feedback that you're now good at what you're doing but it's a conscious effort and you'll screw up if you aren't concentrating enough.
4. Unconscious Competence, you've practiced long enough and put in so much time and effort that you can perform the skill or talk about the subject as easy as walking, you may dip into Conscious Competence if you encounter an infrequent occurrence in your skill or subject but you've got what it takes to get through it

The pattern recognition became very clear to me when I learned Morse code. The human brain takes 50 milliseconds to process and understand a sound. People regularly send and receive Morse code at 30 words per minute, which puts the dit character and the gap between all characters at 40 milliseconds. So you literally have to process sounds faster than the brain can recognize them. Over time you start to hear whole words in the code rather than individual letters, but you still have to decode call signs character by character. You basically cache the sounds in your brain without processing them, and once the whole set of characters passes, your brain is able to turn it into an idea and add it to the stack of previous ideas while your ears are already caching the next set of characters.

3:00 around here, this is a very interesting concept to me because I know from playing chess that we (chess players) are always searching for advantageous positions for ourselves and disadvantageous positions for our opponents. I was never a professional chess player or even an amatuer-pro, but that's what I saw while I played. We're trying to simultaneously outpredict your opponent's positions in the short term and the long term. You're trying to lead them into the worst positions where you can apply leverage. It's a kind of mental jiu-jitsu or mental sparring.

My main point? It makes sense that the "master" can see the most important pieces & general positions on both sides of the board: he has trained his mind to look for them. That's what makes a great master. It's seeing the most important parts as quickly as possible and planning out how to use them all to his advantage. It makes sense that the "master" cannot discern a random board: that's never the purpose of chess games. We're constantly thinking about the positioning of white vs black.

1. Valid environnement

2. Direct feedbacks

3. Leave your comfort zone

You have to push your limit by regularly working on what you're struggling with. It's necessary to not repeat yourself for too long

Hi, just a quick challenge on the claim that driving doesn't improve after 50 or so hours of learning. If you rate the expertise of driving as the ability to get from A to B without crashing (which for most of us is the entire point) then extra experience absolutely does improve your expertise. The data on accident claims, especially those involving injury, is extremely clear. A driver aged around 20 is about 3 times more likely to be involved in an accident than someone aged around 50, which is typically the point of peak performance. This in part is due to older people being more careful, but not entirely - we see the same effect based on driving experience as well. The benefit drops off with every additional year, until around 10 years where it flattens out, stopping at around 20 years.

#4: Don't be comfortable.

This instantly reminded me of H Day in Sweden, the day when everyone switched driving from the left to the right side of the roadways. Many people were certain that it would cause untold deaths and many more accidents. In fact, for many years afterward, accident rates plummeted. The assumption is that people were suddenly paying much closer attention to how they drive. Having driven on the opposite side of the road in another country, I'm sure that it also made driving fairly stressful, but that seems like a fair price to pay for fewer injuries and deaths caused by lazy, comfortable driving habits. #4 is a great, general lesson.

The whole event is rather fascinating. If you're curious to learn more about it, there's a great, short episode by the podcast "99% Invisible" that's worth checking out. It's episode 215, titled "H-Day."

I would argue most economists and political related experts are poor at predictions in their field because they have confirmation bias related to their philosophical outlook. They pass predictions through the filter of their highly emotive politics which impedes their ability to analyze objectively. They want the opposing political force to be the villain in their predictive models and their own politics to be the hero in the narrative. Most fail to appreciate that nature does not line up perfectly to their simplistic political models.

Consider the case of climate change, Rightwing pundits tend to produce predictive models that either claim it doesn't exist, isn't a big problem if it does exist, or if a big problem claim government intervention still isn't the way to solve the issue. On the other hand, leftwing pundits produce economic/regulatory models that claim varying degrees of government intervention is necessary. Both these views are based on assumptions on how the combination of pollution, atmospheric physics, industrial innovation and large number of other scientific and technology factors play out. Not only is neither of these two political factions typically academically equipped to provide a scientific opinion on the issue but even among scientific experts no single person is. The issue is too complex for a single mind to predict with certain outcome. What we are really doing is risk management based on current available evidence that is subject to change.

Perhaps tomorrow some genius in private industry invents a scalable and profitable way to carbon capture by turning it into fuel for ICE engines. That would mean government intervention wasn't necessarily so the rightwing model was right. On the other hand, perhaps the IPCC panel had far too moderate predictions due to pressure from rightwing polemists. Say temperatures rise by an average of 10C in the next century instead. Not only would government intervention be necessary but a significant chunk of the planet would become uninhabitable.

I feel like there is another thing missing: desire/passion. Who is an expert in physics or chess or gymnastics and straight up doesnt like it or didnt like it at some point? Other than sometimes being pressured into piano from a young age, people need some sort of drive or desire to get into being an expert at something. And I found that the general desires of some directly conflict with becoming an expert in anything:
Some people want randomness, spontaneity, unpredictability, a lack of repetition. I personally get bored with repetition. I think some people's passions won't allow for some of these to happen:
Desire for comfort, Diversity (non-repetitive), Softness (not critical, not having much feedback so as not to be too wrong, rigid, stiff, competitive), Chance/Randomness (like the casino or stocks, the random can be exciting and fun, a non-valid environment can be desirable for enjoyment).
I am not an expert in anything, because I desire comfort, I hate repetition, and I don't really trust certain areas of feedback in the few things I do like. I am a meditator, but I don't trust someone to analyze my meditation and give me feedback. Additionally, if I do a work of art that I love, I don't really care if an "expert" approves of it. The things I like usually have feedback that I give myself, and is not external. But then I don't necessarily make things or do things that impress others.

I feel like there is a very important element in many skills that some minimum natural competence or advantage is very helpful- it provides the untrained doer a dopamine hit. It's one reason why left handers are over-represented in competitive sports where handedness is an issue (they tend to win more early on as they are unusual). Example- Playing good jazz requires excellent relative or absolute pitch, to track chord/key changes which are typically somewhat, but not precisely predictable. Some people arrive at jazz naturally with that skill, others need to train it from +/- 0. For some "learning relative pitch from zero" is their 10,000 hour activity, but that does not in fact mean you are in any way good at jazz, yet... The stock thing, historically, has been true. But there are some who are of the opinion that the basic truth of passive index funds performing better than individual stock selection has depended critically on active investment management. Individual stock pickers trading against information on individual stocks or market segments, which tends to (quickly) converge the price on stocks to some optimal, information-priced state. Those same folks now worry that we are in an overly-indexed environment, where not enough individual stock analysis happens, not enough individual trades are made, and, consequently, indices of less-accurately priced stocks may wind up lagging active management.

We'll see! It's an experiment that ought to run itself. It'll be interesting to compare index performance against active management over the next several years, as we (potentially) emerge from a too-passive management environment.

The pattern recognition became very clear to me when I learned Morse code. The human brain takes 50 milliseconds to process and understand a sound. People regularly send and receive Morse code at 30 words per minute, which puts the dit character and the gap between all characters at 40 milliseconds. So you literally have to process sounds faster than the brain can recognize them. Over time you start to hear whole words in the code rather than individual letters, but you still have to decode call signs character by character. You basically cache the sounds in your brain without processing them, and once the whole set of characters passes, your brain is able to turn it into an idea and add it to the stack of previous ideas while your ears are already caching the next set of characters.

My experience with market analysis is very much like chess: there are clear patterns that emerge that are identifiable because you've seen them again and again, kind of like history repeating. It might just be because enough computers trade on the same algorithm, but it's not too hard to see the beginnings of a moving market using moving averages and other indicators. The idea of moving averages in general suggests that even if small movements are seemingly stochastic, larger trends are generalizable and somewhat predictable - it's pyschology and pure maths rather than rational decision making. Using Fibonacci numbers and other 'significant crosses' you can often see patterns in market ebbs and flows - again, mostly because there are just a lot of computers making similar moves on the board, not because Fibonnaci numbers are somehow the matrix underlying the universe. Are my indicators not just small chess pieces on the larger chess board we call 'the market'?

Maybe I'm just like the rest of us trade monkeys tied to some notion that there is somehow order in chaos. I do know one thing that's certain: half the players who play chess will lose...

"Why do people still invest in hedge funds if they can't beat the market?"

The answer is in the name. It's a /hedge/ fund. The point of a hedge fund is to hedge against downside risk. That's why, in the example against Buffett, the hedge funds were winning after the 2008 downturn. It's their job to protect against losses in a bear market, not beat the average in a bull market. If you were retired, which one would you want? A fund that did great in bull markets, or that didn't lose your money in bear markets? That's why hedge funds exist--their job is to protect--not to grow.

The pattern recognition became very clear to me when I learned Morse code. The human brain takes 50 milliseconds to process and understand a sound. People regularly send and receive Morse code at 30 words per minute, which puts the dit character and the gap between all characters at 40 milliseconds. So you literally have to process sounds faster than the brain can recognize them. Over time you start to hear whole words in the code rather than individual letters, but you still have to decode call signs character by character. You basically cache the sounds in your brain without processing them, and once the whole set of characters passes, your brain is able to turn it into an idea and add it to the stack of previous ideas while your ears are already caching the next set of characters.

The one quality not addressed in this video is talent. There’s a school of thought that talent doesn’t exist, that only motivation and the criteria addressed in the video matter. That’s false. If we look, for example, at elite athletes in various sports, we see similar body types within each sport and these body types don’t cross over into other sports. These body types are a physical manifestation of talent. They are obvious and easy to identify.

Talent in non-physical pursuits is harder to identify or even to define, but it can’t be discounted. Certain musicians have a “sense of melody.” Others don’t. Certain painters have an inherent aptitude for, say, composition or color harmony. Others don’t. Certain writers have a poetic bent or an inherent ability to evoke dread or some other emotion. No amount of practice can instill these attributes into someone who doesn’t already have them. All of the criteria covered in the video speak to becoming an expert at those pursuits one is already naturally gifted in.

Something else that goes along with the route to becoming an expert are the 4 stages of learning.
1. Unconscious Incompetence, you're bad but aren't aware of exactly how bad you are because you know very little of the skill or subject you're practicing.
2. Conscious Incompetence, you have a better grasp on the subject knowledge and its depths after putting in a good amount of time and practice but you're not quite good at it yet.
3. Conscious Competence, you've put in enough time and effort with enough feedback that you're now good at what you're doing but it's a conscious effort and you'll screw up if you aren't concentrating enough.
4. Unconscious Competence, you've practiced long enough and put in so much time and effort that you can perform the skill or talk about the subject as easy as walking, you may dip into Conscious Competence if you encounter an infrequent occurrence in your skill or subject but you've got what it takes to get through it 👍

The pattern recognition became very clear to me when I learned Morse code. The human brain takes 50 milliseconds to process and understand a sound. People regularly send and receive Morse code at 30 words per minute, which puts the dit character and the gap between all characters at 40 milliseconds. So you literally have to process sounds faster than the brain can recognize them. Over time you start to hear whole words in the code rather than individual letters, but you still have to decode call signs character by character. You basically cache the sounds in your brain without processing them, and once the whole set of characters passes, your brain is able to turn it into an idea and add it to the stack of previous ideas while your ears are already caching the next set of characters.

Looks like the guy picked funds-of-hedge-funds with, in aggregate, a lower level of risk than the S&P 500 (beta less than 1). As a result, his portfolio lost less in the market crash, but also earned less in the subsequent boom. This was readily predictable. He should have picked only high-beta funds! Or, the competition should have been to see who achieved a higher Sharpe ratio, which is the ratio of excess returns (above the risk free rate) to risk (standard deviation of returns).
Also, passive investors do best in markets with lots of active managers, since the assets are more accurately priced. So the active managers might indeed be getting a lot of calls right, but the passive investors are benefiting too.

It feeds into the old story about the printing press tech. A large newspaper had a printing press break down. The Newspaper hired the best engineer available to fix the problem. After a week of looking at the problem, the engineer decided how to correct the problem. The engineer was satisfied with this decision and tried the printing press. Unfortunately the problem was not fixed and the engineer billed the Newspaper $10,000 for his time and expense's. Being frustrated with the failed attempt to fix the printing press, the Newspaper was at the end of their rope. The Newspaper heard of an old printing press tech ( Non Degree Engineer) who had 30 plus years of experience working on printing press's. Fianaly the Newspaper called the old printing press tech. After looking at the problem for half and hour the old printing press tech made a few tweeks and a few hammer blows. Like magic when he turned on the printing press, it worked flawlessly! The old printing press tech billed the Newspaper $15,000 for his time and expense. The old printing press tech spent a total of 25 minutes to fix the problem. The managers at the Newspaper were very upset with the charges to fix the printing press. When the managers confronted the old printing press tech about the bill, they were mad about paying $15,000 for less than half an hours work! They asked the old printing press tech how could he charge them $15,000 for half an hours work! The old printing press tech responded with " It was 10 minutes to find the problem, 15 minutes to fix the problem and 32 years of experience to learn where to look for the problem! I give you experience always trumps education in many situations! FJB!

As far as markets go, I have worked in them for years and I feel it is not as low validity as one thinks, Overall if you put in the effort and have the knowledge. Stock picking can work tremendously but this also means truly working hard, and having the knowledge of accounting, economics, technical analysis, and fundamental analysis. If one simply has the knowledge of how cycles work, like most commodity cycles, and can track commodities, one can make good guaranteed money but it is not as simple as selecting random stuff. It means to read every single day about what is going on in the world of commodities, the world over. Making money in the market can come down to a lot of accounting knowledge, economic knowledge, a lot of effort, and yes, pure luck.  There are also three golden rules in the market, cut your losses, stick to the winners and never be greedy or fearful. It means being very disciplined. A profit is always better than a loss no matter how small. One of the hardest things in markets is the decision to book a profit or to book a loss and that's where experience truly helps.
