Sorry, perhaps I'm too stupid for this, but I can't get around something here [please don't get me wrong, great video], but in the second point of environment validity you say we can't assume the 20-10% of always successful transactions in the market are successful due to so-called experts, 'cause that success is surely due to other factors [low validity] and not because of their expertise per sé [which means you can't really validate expertise in low validity environments], but immediately after, just some sentences later, you contradict that statement by saying, "I don't mean there are no experts, like Warren Buffet" [who proved he didn't mind the low validity of the environment to be successful, aka a true expert]... You just told us 'A' is not true, just to say that 'A' is true next... Am I missing something?

I can understand that in low validity environments there may be guys randomly hitting the jackpot [so to speak] from time to time more due to luck and other factors rather than expertise, but what about those people that almost always hit it or predict it correctly, and just occasionally don't [precisely 'cause is harder to do so in such environment]? Wouldn't that simply be the 20-10% of success previously mentioned reflecting the expertise of the actual experts, as we first could've assumed but you said we shouldn't? I mean, the best chess player in the world may lose from time to time, does that makes him any less of an expert? Know what I'm saying? [and I understand chess is a not a low validity environment, but the point still remains], in fact I would rather say that if a guy stays on the top of the game in a low validity environment [as many of them do], he is not only an expert, but a genius of his field, which makes the whole low validity environment irrelevant.

TL;DR: Wouldn't it be more accurate to say that a higher rate of desirable results is the thing that truly tells if you are an expert or not, regardless of a low [or high] validity environment? But that would render the whole 2nd point of things it takes to be an expert of this video... pointless.

#4: Don't be comfortable.

This instantly reminded me of H Day in Sweden, the day when everyone switched driving from the left to the right side of the roadways. Many people were certain that it would cause untold deaths and many more accidents. In fact, for many years afterward, accident rates plummeted. The assumption is that people were suddenly paying much closer attention to how they drive. Having driven on the opposite side of the road in another country, I'm sure that it also made driving fairly stressful, but that seems like a fair price to pay for fewer injuries and deaths caused by lazy, comfortable driving habits. #4 is a great, general lesson.

The whole event is rather fascinating. If you're curious to learn more about it, there's a great, short episode by the podcast "99% Invisible" that's worth checking out. It's episode 215, titled "H-Day."

There's another reason why people pick hedge funds. Because hedge funds are more liquid, can rearrange portfolios, and go short, they're valuable whenever there's a downturn. If you're an investor or a business a downturn might mean credit becomes more expensive and your cashflow goes down, so if an investment opportunity comes along you end up not having enough cash lying around to capitalize on it. But hedge funds generally see above average returns during downturns, when credit and cash is more scarce. So for some people it makes sense to have money in hedge funds as a strategy to keep liquidity high at all points of the business cycle.

Take Bill Ackman shorting corporate bonds in the spring of 2020 for example; whoever had their money in his hedge fund would now suddenly see a massive infusion of cash just when it was time to buy the SP500 dip.

Hi Derek, one thing to add about your comment on 10% beating the market average. Neil deGrasse Tyson made a good point about this. If you have 1000 people flip a coin and guess correct, they move on to the next round. Theoretically, the next round (next year in market terms) will have 500 people, then 250, 125, 68, 34... Those 34 people that were correct believe they were smart and used some brilliant strategy when in reality, they were just lucky because theoretically, 34 people were bound to make it to that round. And as the years go on, that number will keep getting smaller.

About that Magnus Carlsen clip recognizing games from positions. The first few examples are indeed impressive, but the last one, where he calls the game after 2 opening moves, that's not as much of a wow thing as it seems. There are literally hundreds of games starting with the moves where he exclaimed it's Anand. There is no way he could have known it was that game. It's just that that Anand game is well known in chess circles, so it was a 'I know where you're going with this' and he guessed right. I'd say that this is also an example of how, in this last case, something can look impressive to a lay audience, while it was in fact a guess that could have been made by many amateurs in the field.

It's also similar with a Rubik's cube. When I first learned years ago I had to write down algorithms and reference them every time I solve the cube and it would be slow. Eventually I memorized the algorithms and I could solve the cube a little bit faster but I would have to recall the algorithms from memory. Even further after that since I've solved Rubik's cubes so many times It's like muscle memory now. My brain doesn't think " R D R' D' " as an algorithm anymore. I just know when to use an algorithm and I simply "just use it" without thinking about it anymore. Also this is in reference to 3x3 standard Rubik's cubes and you would absolutely have to go back to the basics and learn more specific algorithms for anything higher than 3x3. I am also far from the best. The best people at these things memorize algorithms that might only be applicable in one out of every 50 solves or something like that. I only originally memorized six or seven algorithms that appear in every single solve. The algorithms get really deep on this and the chunking is insane The more of them you memorize and practice. And of course once you do it for so long you really don't even think about it. You just do it. Memory is so interesting 🤔

I major takeaway here that I think was missed is that these are criteria for improvement to any level. Becoming an “expert” on guitar may just be the ability to shred along with your favorite band, not necessarily to become a world-touring star yourself. With that in mind, I’d add one more: a clear goal. Sometimes that’s obvious. Magnus was the youngest grandmaster ever (at that time), so his potential to make a living with chess was obvious. But for most of us, the level of expertise we want to (or can afford to) achieve in our career or hobbies is something we need to consider regularly.

My favorite unconscious grammar rule in English is the arrangement of adjectives. Ask me to list the order and I'd fail, but I know that "big old brown fox" feels more correct than "brown old big fox".

For me at least I feel like repetition from popular media helped my English quite a bit. We've heard adjectives arranged in a particular way so many times that we can just know when it's not in the right order, because it'll sound so different to how we usually hear it arranged.

What is also fascinating about this is this is how neural nets are taught to master a singular task. So human and artificial intelligence is t any different. But neural nets require data and synthesis to be able to do the same thing

Doctor thing reminded me of something: I was once told an expert swordsman is not afraid of a skilled opponent, but of a novice. A novice does not do what they are supposed to, and therefore is unpredictable.

If you've ever played an online FPS with a ranking system, this plays out a lot. People who are high ranked can often fail to perform against middle ranked opponents. The key is that middle ranked opponents are often nearly as skilled in things like aiming or movement, but they don't have the same buildup of tactical skillset that is required for high ranked play. This often puts them in unusual or unexpected positions, catching higher ranked players off guard.

For some personal experience: I'm a hobbyist bra maker, and I frequently give out fitting advice to people struggling to make their own bras. When I do this I am frequently at odds with people considered experts - pattern designers, that sort of thing. The advice that they sometimes give is often baffling to me and I think it's because of a lack of actually processing the feedback and getting comfortable.

To give one specific example, if the upper edge of the band (the bit that goes around your back) is loose, you might think that taking a dart out of the pattern along that upper edge (so it becomes shorter in relation to the bottom edge) will increase the tension along that upper band, but actually it doesn't. I used to think this but I realised after seeing people do this alteration and it not working for them (actually making the situation worse) I revisited the theory and came up with a new understanding of that alteration. And still pattern designers suggest that alteration, despite discussing it in private. They just suggest the alteration, because it makes immediate logical sense, and don't actually evaluate the feedback given in the form of new photographs.

I suppose what I've learned is that feedback is very important, but actually engaging with that feedback (so I suppose "deliberate practice") is absolutely required to make the feedback even worth it for complex systems

This was a fun video to watch because it created some structure around what I've observed in my field to be predictors of success and failure for machine learning in my field (health IT). I've been justifiably skeptical of the ability for ML (or AI) to "solve" cancer for all the reasons mentioned (latency, squishy endpoints, and even pharmacology or surgical techniques advancing faster than the machine learning curve). Where algorithmic predictive models have worked well are in scenarios where disease progression happens fast (heart attacks, stroke, sepsis) and the end-points are fairly concrete (go home alive, die, or get discharged to a rehab facility).

Connection to Western Technologies
Forced organ harvesting is not an issue that involves merely China. “Eminent [Western] medics are starting to look back uncomfortably on decades of “constructive engagement” with the Chinese medical establishment – those all-expenses-paid trips to lecture budding surgeons, and the profitable arrangements to train batches of them in the west,” wrote the article.

Professor Russell Strong, a world-renowned Australian transplant doctor, called last October, “on all Chinese surgeons to be banned from western hospitals to prevent them using the skills they pick up there in the organ harvesting market.”

“All this implies a disturbing question. Namely, has the west aided and abetted China’s organ harvesting industry?” explained the article, “Or, in more human terms, if Yang had stuck around in Beijing to have her living heart cut out, might that surgeon have received relevant training from a British university, or even the NHS (National Health Service)?”

A Supply Chain
One known fact is that that global demand for organs vastly outstrips legitimate supply. Professor Martin Elliott from London’s Great Ormond Street Hospital said organs are often desperately sought. This led to an organ tourism market worth about $1.7 billion a year. A Japanese woman even paid $5 million for a liver, the article stated.

These transplant “agents” are available in many countries and health insurance companies in Israel even used to offer help to clients finding such agents in China. Although such incentives are understandable, “what is less clear to the casual observer is how in a couple of short decades China managed to become the organ transplant centre of the world.”

Wayne Jordash QC, founder of Global Rights Compliance, tried to find the answer. “At the beginning of the 2000s the PRC leapt from a follower to a leader of transplantation technology,” he said. “Transplant tourists and Chinese citizens were reported to have access to a matched organ within weeks or months, in comparison to other countries where patients could be on a transplant waiting list for years despite well-established donation systems.”

The next question is the source of the ample supply of these organs. The Chinese authorities said in 2009 that two-thirds of organs used for transplantations were taken from death row prisoners. “But that simply didn’t stack up. From 2000, the number of executions following a death penalty sentence declined, while the transplantation system grew exponentially,” explained the article.

That is why people turned to Falun Gong, a meditation system harshly suppressed by Chinese Communist Party (CCP). “Mass arrests followed. Since then the number of Falun Gong practitioners who have fallen victim to forced organ harvesting are, conservatively, estimated to amount to hundreds of thousands,” wrote the article, “According to Sir Geoffrey Nice’s China Tribunal, 60,000 to 100,000 transplantations took place annually between 2000 and 2014, with Falun Gong practitioners serving as the principal source.”

Several years after forced organ harvesting was exposed, China said in 2010 that organ procurement from executed prisoners would end in 2015 and be replaced with voluntary donation. “But experts don’t believe that for a minute. They point out that the number of organs used in China for transplantations greatly outstrips the number that could ever be garnered from voluntary donation,” wrote the article.

Love the video, but I do have to say that the purpose of a hedge fund isn't to increase gains. It is almost exclusively fixated on minimizing downside risk so in times of economic crisis, hedge funds will lose significantly less. It's in their name, they hedge their bets. Over long term the market may return more but the historic volatility and implied volatility are higher and risks higher losses. A hedge fund has much lower historic and implied volatility in it's returns so the highs and lows are evened out. It is really just a way for rich investors to secure their money in volatile market conditions. If they were worried about making more money then they would bite the risk and put all of their money in an index. They worked hard for what they have, most of the time, so they don't want to lose it, but they are money conscious so they don't want it to stagnate in a bank account.

TL;DW: To get good at something...
1. 6:46 It must be something which is possible to get good at. You can't predict random numbers, for example, or the outcome of novel events.

3. 13:50 You must keep pushing your limits and trying new things, instead of repeating the same old things.
4. 5:00 You must do an awful lot of it.
... and people who get too comfortable tend to get worse at what they do. So if you become an expert, don't stop... instead, you gotta keep learning, keep sharpening your skills.

Hi Derek, the documentary is fascinating, and I definitely learned something new. Much appreciated! However, one thing that went completely out of the window here is the role of talent and genetic influences. Heritability studies would have been important to at least mention here as they clearly show the impact of genes. As for deliberate practice: A meta-analysis from 2016 found that deliberate practice hours predicts 26% of the variance in games such as chess, 21% for music, and 18% for sports according to a quite recent meta-analysis (Macnamara BN, Moreau D, Hambrick DZ. The Relationship Between Deliberate Practice and Performance in Sports: A Meta-Analysis. Perspect Psychol Sci. 2016 May;11(3):333-50. doi: 10.1177/1745691616635591. PMID: 27217246.) Thus, most of the variance (i.e., “differences” among individuals in a trait under consideration) is, in fact, not explained by deliberate practice but other factors and presumably some interactions.

Perhaps the claims made by Ericsson were clearly exaggerated and not just some kind of misinterpretation made by the audience.

A recent study titled "Smart people know how the economy works: Cognitive ability, economic knowledge and financial literacy" showed that higher IQ was a better predictor of economic knowledge than educational attainment or economics courses.

I think definetely this is the case with debugging and programming. In the beginning many programmers get frustrated with their code because they don't understand how to debug it or just want to make it work. Programmers can get complacent and comfortable with "working" code even if they don't fully understand how their own code works or why a particular solution works. To get better at programming, one has to deliberately practice in that they must make themselves uncomfortable by delving into why certain things work and why certain things don't.

After some time, patterns start to emerge. Many novice programmers are often amazed that I can, by intuition, find many obscure bugs. But to me, these aren't that obscure. I'm just recognizing a pattern that I've spent many hours puzzling over that's reappearing.

The "10,000 hours" bs is from Malcolm Gladwell, who makes stuff up, then cherry picks facts to suit his needs and support his assertions, all the while pretending to just be reporting on scientific things in a scientific way.
I first "cottoned on" when he detailed how hockey players ended up reaching high levels mostly due to the time of year they were born. His premise was that the age cutoff (i'll be "remembering from memory" here, so the dates/leagues etc used for illustration purposes only!) throughout a player's youth was September 30th and therefore any kid born shortly after that would be older (hence bigger,stronger,more mature) than an otherwise equal kid born just before that cut off date and therefore have quite an advantage. Almost one year's growth from 11 years old to 12 can be huge. The bigger and stronger kid would then impress more, be chosen for better teams, get better coaching, play against better opposition, play in more serious and meaningful games, practice more often, and this would compound year after year.
He then showed this to be true using mock "play by play" of a major junior game in the Western Hockey League calling players by their birth date instead of their names. It was really well done well and brought home the point he was making. He used real players, their real birth dates, from a real game. And showed how over 60% of the players were born in Oct-Jan, 30% from Feb-May, and less than 10% from June-Sept.
I swallowed it hook, line, and sinker. I was intrigued and looked into other sports with specific cut off dates but found no pattern and became curious. Was this just a "hockey" thing"? I then kinda realized it was odd that Mr. Gladwell pick two teams from a major junior league and not the main professional league (the NHL) so i picked a team at random in the NHL and found no striking correlation, then looked league wide and there wasn't any. Well, maybe the cut off dates didn't apply to non Canadians in the league so eliminated them. Still nothing.
I looked another comparable league the Ontario Hockey League and again the data didn't back up Gladwell. So i lastly went back at all the teams in the WHL the same season he used, and only two were heavily rostered by Oct-Dec babies, the two he chose!!!
That f ing cherry picking sob i said to myself!
I them looked into a couple other claims he made in his books, and found similar things. This "brilliant" out of the box thinker communicating weird and wonderful things in a scientific way was a charlatan, a smooth talking snake oil salesman making me believe in things and backing it up with fake claims and selling me all the answers.
Fool me once, shame on you, fool me twice…
But Malcom Gladwell never said 10,000hr is ALL you need. He actually said what you are saying, a deliberate intention to improve.

I learned and memorized the entire Elements Song by Tom Lehrer by printing out the lyrics and sticking them to my bathroom door. Every time I brushed my teeth I would review the words in 2 minute chunks. Eventually I had to listen to the song on my phone when I walked my dogs but at half the speed. Then it got to the point where I learned the entire song. And now many years later the entire periodic table of elements is stored in one chunk of data rather than lots of individual chunks like it was when I was learning it. In fact, there becomes a point where if I sing the song too slow I forget the next word. I have to sing it at speed otherwise I won't be able to remember what's next. It is amazing what the human brain can do, it only took 2 weeks to learn. incredible.

Oh wow I was just studying Miller's chunking concept and zone of proximal development in Vygotsky's learning theory! Usually in textbooks they explain chunking with vocabulary memorization examples such as chunking all word that remind you of school under the umbrella word school so when you need to remember those many many words your active memory pulls that umbrella term and unpacks it to recall other smaller units such as exam, paper, teacher, desk, stress, play, math etc. Another example that is widely used to describe chunking in short-term memory is chunking telephone numbers. Short term memory can only hold up to between 7-10 units of information at a time, so if you have a phone number that goes like 1234567891, you can't memorize it like that in short term memory because evey single number is one unit of information. So you quickly chunk it to 123-456-78-91 this time it is made up of 4 chunks and you can still perform other tasks while keeping the phone number in your mind to use. But chess master example is a novelty to me. I've never thought they were that good at recognizing patterns at a single gaze because of chunking. This is so much better as an example. I'll use it in my studies.

Well presented. I'm a fifer and drummer in a fife and drum corps. For 40 years. Drummers chunk. Especially rudimental drummers. Chunk 0; 7 flam flam. Chunk 1; end-of-a-roll-tap-tap flam-accent, chunk 2; flam flam flam. Chunk 3; 7 15 15. Boom 400 tunes in 6/8 time signature by combining the chunks in different ways. Add complexity by adding chunk 4, maybe ratamaqueues, or chunk 5 maybe a sextuplet. etc. And you can get mediocre fairly quickly, but to advance, you have to deliberately practice, have to stretch into new tools, regular practice with others etc. I've seen plenty of musicians over the years plateau because they simply get in a rut, rarely play with partners or worse, don't practice. And yes, many young drummers quickly outpace their instructors because they take the steps to become an expert when their instructor has stopped progressing.

Un moteur électrique (AC / DC) consommera, en ampères, jusqu'à 10 fois son courant normal pleine puissance lorsqu'il est arrêté (Locked Rotor Amperes, ou LRA).

Or, une rame de Métro a une masse considérable (325 tonnes) et appliquer la pleine tension (750 volts) aux moteurs de traction au démarrage est totalement suicidaire.

Pour limiter le courant au démarrage, les toutes premières rames MR-63, équipées de moteurs à courant continu (DC) utilisaient des résistances de haute puissance.

Ces résistances fonctionnaient bien sauf qu'elles consommaient une très haute puissance électrique (rendement médiocre) en plus de dégager une très forte chaleur dans les stations.

Les voitures MR-73, équipées de thyristors (SCR), fonctionnaient de façon différente: Elles alimentaient les moteurs DC à pleine tension, via des inductances, et coupaient ce courant plusieurs centaines de fois par seconde, ce qui générait les fameux "dou-dou-douuuuu" typique de ces voitures. Le pourcentage de temps où la pleine tension était appliquée (duty cycle) servait à contrôler la quantité de puissance délivrée aux moteurs.

Ces hacheurs de courant, tels qu'on les appelle, sont nettement plus efficaces et dégagent moins de chaleur que les vieilles résistances, mais les MR-73 utilisaient toujours des moteurs DC.

Or, ces moteurs sont aujourd'hui complètement désuets pour la traction. Que ce soit pour les locomotives, les rames de métro, les voitures électriques, les ascenseurs, les pompes ou la ventilation haute puissance, ils ont tous été remplacés par des moteurs AC triphasés (à courant alternatif).

Ces moteurs AC, sans balais, plus simples, sont beaucoup plus fiables, dégagent moins de poussière et requièrent moins d'entretien que les moteurs DC.

Or, ces moteurs AC, qui existent depuis 1900, étaient totalement inaptes pour utilisation en traction ou dans les ascenseurs puisqu'ils tournaient à une vitesse fixe en courant alternatif et étaient essentiellement limités à des utilisation à vitesse fixe puisque leurs rotors suivaient essentiellement le champ magnétique rotatif dégagé par le stator et cette vitesse de rotation suit rigoureusement la fréquence du secteur (60 Hz en Amérique du Nord, 50 Hz en Europe).

Or, avec l'avènement de transistors rapides de type MOSFET et IGBT considérablement plus puissants, des alimentations triphasées à fréquence variable (appelés VFD) on pu être développés. On peut désormais développer un courant triphasé de la fréquence que l'on désire, et ce, de 0 Hz jusqu'à la fréquence du secteur. Non seulement, on peut faire tourner un moteur AC à la vitesse que l'on désire, mais aussi, le démarrage de ces moteurs est beaucoup plus doux et progressif.

Le défaut des moteurs AC à vitesse fixe disparaissait donc à tout jamais et aujourd'hui ils sont devenus la norme. Je suis sûr à 100 % que les nouvelles voitures Azur utilisent cette technologie.

Quant à cette vidéo, bravo !!! Je n'avais jamais entendu une rame MR-73 démarrer en mode manuel auparavant.

I figured this out pretty early on in life, and though I didn't break it down in to 4 parts, I learned some key things that let me learn at speeds my peers didn't understand.

Deliberate practice is one of the most important ones on that list. Deliberate practice must cover two areas though. Fundamentals and new stuff. With guitar I deliberately practiced a number of scales. These are simple, but these fundamental movements allow for more advanced play and improvisation. The "new stuff" involved me seeking out existing guitar "experts". I would ask them how they did some specific thing, or technique. I'd study it and fail a lot while they attempted to help me. Then I'd leave, go home, and play for 4-6 hours. Deliberately practicing and failing at the technique I was after. At some point it would all click, I could suddenly sweep pick a certain scale with relative ease. You cannot stop there. You must continue that new thing learned and play with it to keep it challenging. A few days later I would return to another expert guitar player I knew and ask them to teach me something new.

Years later friends explained to me that they were jealous of how quickly I learned guitar. They also practiced very hard and had played longer than me as I only learned at 18. I was armed with an understanding of learning though. It has always come natural to me to learn in this fashion. Finding the edge of comfort and... playing with it.

I quit practicing after 5 or 6 years and now I'm a husk of what I once was as a guitar player. I'm still okay, but now it's more of a party trick to play a flamenco "scale" or a blues riff. I wonder what my life would have been like had I continued and become a musician. Probably failure.

"Practice makes perfect" is one of the biggest BS the school taught me.

The doctors' example really hit home. When seeing General Practitioners, they're far more likely to be hit with commonplace ailments & will openly push back on diagnoses of rare conditions (especially with the current barrage of online Pseudo-Scientific Disinformation).

"When hearing hoofbeats, think Horses, not Zebras...", is a phrase I've actually had doctors parrot at me when going through the same round of common tests again - even after prior doctors had repeatedly eliminated all possible commonplace illnesses - simply because their copious prior experience had demonstrated the efficacy of doing these basic tests first.

After a while, my response was: "Well, what if it's a Unicorn?", meaning something that's so rare, or unique that they've never experienced it before, and have even been actively trained to reject it as impossible..? As it turns out, the answer is that they'll get irritable - even angry. You see, apart from being an Expert, they've had thousands of successes in making accurate diagnoses (each accompanied by that requisite Dopamine hit). Imagine how you'd feel as a YouTube producer if the company arbitrarily changed it's popularity algorithim (yet, again) & suddenly - despite doing the exact same things which had brought you myriad successful Dopamine hits - you're no longer getting the same results. How would this make you feel? Bloody pissed off.

[ This mindset goes some way to explain why it took me the better part of a decade to get an accurate diagnosis, of what turns out to be a relatively common condition. It was so outside their experience that they simply lacked the tools to diagnose it, with the tools they had had used for their entire careers actively hampering them from making an accurate diagnosis. It took a doctor who both specialised in Pain conditions, & who had seen the condition in patients before, to recognise it. ]

I subconsciously learn to understand,write and speak english this way. I learn to understand english by learning vocabularies on elementary school, I hated learning english the way school teach it, but one day i discovered youtube and the rest is history. At first i couldn't comprehend any sentence, and then I step out of my comfort zone and force myself to listen to any familiar words that match my vocabulary bank i already know and recognize grammar pattern in english. It was painfully slow when i look back at it now to be honest but back then i just have the mindset that i have to understand these english yt videos. So bit by bit i understand pieces on a sentence and kept improving on my comprehension skill, i looked up every new words i discover. I learn to write via yt comment and an app for speaking correctly. I now can speak english fluently. All my way to learn English directly correlated with the 4 points of this video and i just realize it now
1. Repetition (I watch youtube as entertainment and education platform almost everyday)
2. Immideate Feedback (Whether i can understand the topic or not and millions of grammar police i've encountered across social medias)
3. Valid Environment ( English is predictable enough)
4. Deliberate Practice (I practice by listening to YT vids, movies,podcasts,etc., I often express myself through comments in english, and i learn to speak via an app and discord calls with my gaming friends.

This is definitely effective on being good and eventually becomes an expert at a lot of things.

I developed a weird skill when I was younger, but without deliberate practice. It happened just from doing it over and over.

I was a tradesman, and this required me to go to up to ten different peoples' houses per day. This was in the days before GPS, so I had to use a physical map to navigate my large home city to the different addresses. The weird skill wasn't my ability to read maps (although I became very good at that), but rather my ability to always find my way back home without using the map.

Simply using the map to navigate to the customer once was enough to imprint the route into my memory, regardless of how complex the route was. This happened without any deliberate intent, and the ability faded after a few years when I changed jobs.

@10:00 stock picking is an area for expertise, there is feedback. The problem is neoclassical economics is wrong, and stock analysts use it, they believe rational agents determine stock prices. An MMT (or even Austrian Sch'er) expert will point out a lot of stock trading is Minksy unstable: there is hedging (betting), then speculation (gambling), then finally ponzi position, whenever there is no anchor for a stock price. Like crypto. Even Nassim Taleb had to admit this, see his Bitcoin Black Paper.
The stock market casino could be eliminated by capping all stock issue at $2, fixed trading price. The company seeking to raise currency can then just issue more stock instead of using the ponzi scheme dynamic of relying on the trading price. This would practically eliminate most stock crashes, the crashes would become reality based - on sales of real goods and real production figures. It would also keep allowing firms to raise investment currency, which was the original purpose of stock markets, they were supposed to raise capital (machinery) purchasing (true capitalism), not raise private wealth based on non-productive profit taking (rentierism).

I would see a problem and i would just know the answer like a sound in my head but in the beginning i didn't trust it and solve the problem and then it would be the same.

Valid Environment
It IS: Regular situations, terrains, boards, events, etc (at least somewhat predictable)
It’s NOT: Inconsistent situations, terrains, boards, environments, etc (they are mostly random)

Many Repetitions
It IS: Experience bucles, grinding until doing something by instinct, gets you muscle memory and chunking (abstraction).
It’s NOT: Skipping, procrastinating.

Timely Feedback
It IS: Quick enough, relevant, specific.
It’s NOT: Delayed (so much that it’s deemed irrelevant), inexistent or random.

Deliberate Practice
It IS: Challenging, hard, either slow-hyper-focused or almost too fast to keep up with it, coached, critiqued (constructively).
It’s NOT: Sitting in a comfort zone.

I consider myself an expert in sailing, yet I have at most 2 000 hours. I'm not a world champion and like most experts I'm still improving, but I can get quite close to them in certain conditions. You see, a world champion is just an expert at the race location in their specific class (which is a tremendous amount of work though). A more specific thing I'm an expert at: predicting what the wind will do, or even more specific: reading ripples on the water and predicting what the wind will do within the next 5 seconds. That only took me 100 hours spread over 2 years while I was in a sailing team. It's a small task, but it adds to the whole. Having small goals helps you find the things you need to be able to learn them fast

On the other hand, my engineering degree took me 10 000 hours instead of the "regular" 6 500. It's more complex with less similarities to do engineering well than it is to know how to find the fastest way to sail

The pattern recognition became very clear to me when I learned Morse code. The human brain takes 50 milliseconds to process and understand a sound. People regularly send and receive Morse code at 30 words per minute, which puts the dit character and the gap between all characters at 40 milliseconds. So you literally have to process sounds faster than the brain can recognize them. Over time you start to hear whole words in the code rather than individual letters, but you still have to decode call signs character by character. You basically cache the sounds in your brain without processing them, and once the whole set of characters passes, your brain is able to turn it into an idea and add it to the stack of previous ideas while your ears are already caching the next set of characters.

comment_text: The pattern recognition became very clear to me when I learned Morse code. The human brain takes 50 milliseconds to process and understand a sound. People regularly send and receive Morse code at 30 words per minute, which puts the dit character and the gap between all characters at 40 milliseconds. So you literally have to process sounds faster than the brain can recognize them. Over time you start to hear whole words in the code rather than individual letters, but you still have to decode call signs character by character. You basically cache the sounds in your brain without processing them, and once the whole set of characters passes, your brain is able to turn it into an idea and add it to the stack of previous ideas while your ears are already caching the next set of characters.

I would add one more criteria.  >>> Recall <<<  Many experts that study .. studying .. state that you can practice all you want, but if you're not challenging your brains ability to recall the information, it won't matter how many times you repeat the process.  This recall process also exposes another area of learning problems for ADHDrs who have associated memory systems, vs rule based systems.  If you teach an ADHDr something in one environment, and then change that environment, they won't be able to recall it. or have a very long time till they are able to recall it.  This becomes especially true with Math as many ADHDrs cant remember the rules of math as they move from one form of math to another.  Take for example learning division, fractions, and ratios. All are based on the same concept, but are broken into distinct areas.   Or, take learning math for fractions and then ask someone to use them in baking. The change in environment confuses them, their recall is significantly slower. Thus, people with ADHD need to be exposed to the same issues in many different environments to recall things they are being asked to remember.

The pattern recognition is something that you have to get used to in language learned obviously, but specifically in learning Kanji/Hanzi. Chinese characters (thank god Japanese only uses 2200 of them). Each character is made of radicals (not extremist zealots lol), smaller components that have their own meanings. There are 214 radicals and they're like puzzle pieces that can be arranged in different ways. The radicals can have a semantic meaning and a phonetic reading. The former will tell you the theme of the word and the latter might tell you how to pronounce it since most characters using that matter radical arrangement are often homophones.

One way to remember kanji in the beginning is to create stories out of the radicals. 壊す means to break, destroy demolish and is made of 土 earth 十 ten/lid 罒 net (just Eye rotated 99°) and 衣 clothes. You could prob make a better story but the one I came up with was
I Close (sounds like clothes) my Eye Lids and wait Ten minutes for the Earth to stop shaking and BREAKING, DEMOLISHING, DESTROYING my surroundings.
Thats typically how you remember them at first, but it's not realistic to go through analyzing each character while trying to read, so as you get better and better, you begin to just recognize the kanji based on its shape. 4:37 Malcolm Gladwell may have popularized it, but Swedish psychologist K. Anders Ericsson discovered this apparent rule when it comes to achieving expert performance. His theory is called "deliberate practice". Hours of practice by themselves are not enough, tho. The practice must be deliberate and challenge the individual to stretch his abilities.

Fun factoid, 10,000 hr ≈√2 yrs
So according to the video you need at least a net of root 2 years to be an expert in addition to other stuff from the vid.

FOUR THINGS YOU NEED TO BECOME AN EXPERT

1. valid environment (structured, patterned)

2. many repetitions (not once-in-a-lifetime thing)

3. timely feedback (feedback as soon as you perform an action)

4. deliberate practice (practice outside of your comfort zone, at the edge of our ability, the zone of proximal learning)

The 10,000-hour rule has been debunked many times over. It's not at all helpful in this video to repeat this number as if it were true or any accurate measure of time needed for expertise. It's not a real number. It's bunk science, one of those intellectual myths that needs to die.

The original research from which that number was drawn was not scientific. It was a survey of people at varying levels of musical accomplishment, which the researchers already labeled from the start. There was no prediction and test of that prediction. There was no study of people from similar starting places showing relative improvement compared against practice time. It was just a survey of people already labeled "expert" and "novice" or "elite" and "amateur" that asked them to self-report how much they had practiced over their musical lifetimes. Even as a survey method, it was deeply flawed. Want a shining example of an "expert" study that utterly failed because the experts running it didn't give themselves a research model with any meaningful, immediate feedback? This is it.

When Gladwell took this research, misapplied it, and promoted a 10,000-hour rule, he was intellectually irresponsible. The survey didn't show any such rule. Gladwell took an already flawed survey and stretched it into something horribly other than what it was. It was pop psychology that sold well and pushed Gladwell up the NYT bestseller list, but the 10,000-hour rule was a lie.

Subsequent research has suggested that expertise can come at a very wide range of practice hours. (One study found anywhere between 728 hours and 16,120 hours of deliberate practice.) There's also strong evidence that even extensive practice time and the four factors discussed in this video aren't enough---identical twins show similar aptitudes that fraternal twins do not, suggesting that at least some part of ability is genetic. Individuals are not all made equally. No amount of chess practice with feedback in a valid environment, etc., will bring me anywhere close to Magnus Carlsen. I could become very good at chess, and I can enjoy the game a lot, but even if I practiced well ten times as much as Carlsen has over his lifetime, I'd still not be able to beat him. His natural chess aptitude is simply higher than that of nearly every other person on the planet.

Please put this 10,000-hour myth to bed. Like the whole "learning styles" myth, we need to be rid of it.

The Buffet challenge is not a valid data point, because hedge funds have huge costs. If the costs were removed, then their pure skill could be put against the index funds complete passivity. Of course, if you actually want to beat the market, you can't ignore costs, but from an ivory tower perspective, we only care if the experts can do better than the average, not can they actually win after costs. Another problem is that many hedge funds don't stay in business for 10 years, especially if they suck, which would also add a level of bias, because only the winners will be around in 10 years, which rewards risk taking, since the failures are removed from the list.

It's the presence of the ability of pattern recognition to factor in. In the chess example, the layouts were completely novel to every party involved. It could be the layout of Cheetos on a checkerboard. If you were to show the same board again then pattern recognition would play a part and the differentiator would be the individual's ability to recognize the patterns. The paper described at 5:21 seems misguided to me. The overall finding of the paper about repetitions and feedback is fine, but the idea that to be an 'expert' in economics you need to be able to predict future economic trends is absolutely ridiculous. Economics is about identification and modelling, not prediction. To ask an economist in the 90s whether or not the dot com bubble will burst is akin to asking a biologist whether, in a certain instance, a lion will successfully hunt a zebra. It's really frustrating to see people misinterpret my field of research so often!

TLDR: In painting and drawing is there a way to get Timely Feedback without having someone who is already an expert looking over your shoulder?

When it comes to painting and drawing - painting from life satisfies many of these requirements. The appearance of hues, chroma, and values is an orderly system that can be modeled in your mind, and predicting the behavior of light on form can be made your second nature. so that is the Valid Environment. The Deliberate Practice is satisfied by pushing yourself with the content presented to you from life , you can try to get more detail, more accurate, more quick to a result. Painting from life always has another challenge for you to explore. The Many Repetitions is probably always the most straight forward, in this case you just keep trying your best to get it over and over.
My issue is the Timely Feedback - producing a painting or drawing can take a lot of time and you don't always get feedback for every mark you make, sometimes you must make many marks or even finish the image to get meaningful feedback. Any ideas on how to obtain a more Timely Feedback in the context of painting/drawing/image making. Thank you in advance for you thoughts.

At XCOR I spent 17 years struggling to develop multiple generations of rocket engines, igniters, pumps, valves, fluid systems, and thermodynamic cycles on a shoestring budget with limited resources. We did hardware turns as fast as we could and tested the hell out of them. Everything was done in a rush, but in very repeatable environments, with almost instant feedback, and many opportunities to fail, fix, and try again. In those years we designed 27 engines, built and ran 13 of them, at least four pump designs, multiple valves, test stands, controllers, two rocket planes...

Back when I played football my coach would say it takes 10,000 hours to perfect something, and I believed that for a long time. But then I came across LoL and Dota 2. People there spend thousands of hours playing the game, not rarely above 10,000 and yet they play at a skill level nowhere near a really talented player with just 1,000 hours. Just because you put the time in doesn't mean you will get good at something, it really just means that you spent a lot of time.

This also comes down to survivorship bias, the people at the top of their field spent that much time, but that doesn't mean the ones who are below average didn't spend an equal amount of time, it's just a property that occurs in almost all people at the very top, but also in a decent portion of the people who aren't

TLDW: Deliberate learning
Every veritasium video makes you think and eventually ends up giving goosebumps when reality hits.
People using Anki be like :

Deliberate = Attention plus Intention.
I learned this quote from a guitar instructor years ago. I think it defines Deliberate and integrates feedback into guitar practice. Slow down and watch exactly what our fingers are doing. Singular focus on position, and not the resulting song. This is paying Attention to the result. When our fingers don’t fluently go where we want them to, we look for the reason. The reason could be either mechanical or strategic. Now when we practice, we move our fingers in the way that we know is right. It is Intentional, even if it is uncomfortable or unfamiliar at first. By repeatedly, and slowly, placing our fingers in a deliberate position, our brain will slowly shift that pattern into system 2.

She also had another quote. “Practice does not make perfect, practice makes permanent”. If we repeatedly make the same mistake, we are only reinforcing it and making it permanent. This is why at least a portion of our practice needs to be deliberate and intentional.

There may also be an underlying psychological driver. Why are we practicing in the first place? Is our mind floating off to what others might think, to achieve a specific goal, just for enjoyment… I haven’t thought it through, but my intuition is telling me that psychology is related to whether were willing to do the uncomfortable part of practice.

Pattern recognition is in my opinion the most important aspect. I played piano for many years when my ability to read sheet music suddenly increased by a lot. I stopped reading individual notes and started to see chords or intervals. And sometimes I just make assumptions what the chord could be and checking it is faster for me than trying to see it. So I might get wrong chords/notes but they still sound okay since it's all based on patterns.

The "10,000 hour rule" is also +-2 magnitudes. For some, it only takes 100 hours, for  someone else 1,000,000 hours. 10k hours is more the median. Some of this is explained by neurodiveristy. Some people just "naturally" understand certain problem domains in such a way that they need almost no experience at all. This tends to happen in domains where thinking is more important than knowledge or experience.

The pattern recognition became very clear to me when I learned Morse code. The human brain takes 50 milliseconds to process and understand a sound. People regularly send and receive Morse code at 30 words per minute, which puts the dit character and the gap between all characters at 40 milliseconds. So you literally have to process sounds faster than the brain can recognize them. Over time you start to hear whole words in the code rather than individual letters, but you still have to decode call signs character by character. You basically cache the sounds in your brain without processing them, and once the whole set of characters passes, your brain is able to turn it into an idea and add it to the stack of previous ideas while your ears are already caching the next set of characters.

Great content and thought provoking. I'm a radiologist with almost 20 years of experience in breast imaging. I'd like to indicate that our task in breast cancer diagnosis is not to actually determine if a finding is malignant or not. Rather, to look for features that are concerning for cancer, In which case we would do a biopsy. As we try to err on the side of caution, the usaual statistic quoted is that 70% of the biopsies are actually cancers. Therefore, this apparent "low" rate of accuracy is not a reflection of poor performance, nor is it related to a lack of feedback. In actuality each case we biopsy is followed by an accurate pathology report within days. Radiologists are involved in multidisciplenary rounds with our clinical colleagues and we also have internal quality assurance measures to ensure a high level of competence.

For people that are interested in deliberate practice, I'm a member of a research group from Brazil and we are evaluating the extent to which Brazilian popular pianists have employed deliberate practice in their life, I can help with a little more information:


Deliberate practice has 7 principles (if you want you to incorporate it in you study) and 5 criteria (if you want to recognize it in someone's study):

The principles: (1) DP develops abilities that have been learned by other people and that teacher and experts already created techniques that have been tested and are known to lead to improvement; (2) DP happens outside of you comfort zone and because of that, it demands a lot of effort and usually isn't pleasurable; (3) DP need clear and defined goals for improvement of performance. A long-term goal is set and the teacher or coach makes a series of smaller goals that together allow the attainment of the larger goal; (4) DP involves full attention and conscient actions, the student need to be active regarding the goals and demands of the training task; (5) DP needs immediate and clear feedback usually provided by a teacher, by in the case of the principles, it's been said that it could be provided by the practioner if he has enough expertise; (6) DP is based upon and build more mental representations. The performance improvement lead to more detailed and effective mental representations which in turn allow for better performance improvement; (7) DP engages in the modification of specific abilities that the individual already had before the practice. It either modifies an old ability, or builds a new one over the other one leading to performance improvement.

The criteria: (1) the task has to be defined with clear goals that are understood by the subject; (2) the subjects have to be capable of accomplishing the tasks alone; (3) the subjects need to receive immediate feedback of each performance and that feedback needs to be informative and helpful in order to direct appropriate adjustments that lead to performance improvement; (4) the subject needs to be capable of executing repeatedly the same task or similar tasks; (5) the practice task needs to be developed and executed as per instruction and guidance of a teacher or coach.

It's always been a bit unclear of to me of how to actually do deliberate practice, but videogames out of all things have helped me figure it out.
Essentially, whenever you become somewhat comfortable with something you learned, try mixing it up a bit so it's no longer something you can comfortably do with little thought. Try doing it faster or slower so that it forces you to really think about what you're doing, or at the same time as something else or swapping back and fourth between them rapidly, or just try a bunch of different things with it. And once those expansions become more comfortable you mix it up more.
You kind of juggle your skills where whenever you got a grasp on something you toss it up again and change something so you need to work just a bit harder.

And if you get used to doing that and just sorta do it with everything you do everyone will think you're really talented.
It's kinda like speedrunning getting good at something, but to fully master something you need to keep it up all throughout, and importantly, you need to go back to the fundamentals every now and then.
Timely feedback can be tricky, in a dance school some students can't tell if what they are doing is wrong or not, even looking themselves in a mirror. That's why a teacher is so important.

I wonder how fair the study feeding political scenarios at experts is. Presumably those scenarios are scenarios because they’re unexpected. An expert will be able to answer “will the senate sit next week” with extreme accuracy where a non expert will have no idea.

Point being that there’s harder predictions and easier predictions.

For the chess, there's one other major factor: AGE.

I say this as a 39-year-old who has spent well over 10,000 hours of dedicated practice in chess since I was 15. Put in the 10,000 hours starting from age 5 to 20, good chance of reaching GM. Learn the game at 20, and it's unlikely any amount of training will get you there. Maybe if you're endowed with a one in a million brain and immediately began studying 10 hrs/day with an exceptional coach, or were already a pro shogi or go player... But the odds are stacked against you, and you will peak below your genetic potential.

As for me? Competent, yes. Knowledgeable, sure. Master? Afraid not. I used to think it was possible to defy the odds, but that hasn't been the case. To be honest, it doesn't really matter. The number of people I would be able to beat as a master that I can't already is rather insignificant as a percentage of the population, and being a master doesn't mean you can earn a living in chess (which I did at one point, and it was awesome!) The main thing is to enjoy the road.

I am doing a PhD in applied Deep Reinforcement Learning and I find it fascinating how all of the requirements that you lay out here for becoming an expert as a human are identical to the requirements for a machine to learn how to perform well at their assigned task.

In my free time I love to do speedcubing, solving a Rubiks cube as fast as possible. Whilst working a lot with neural networks learning to improve through deliberate interactions with their environment I quickly noticed that the trend lines in improvement seemed to match my own improvement in the time it takes for me to solve the cube. Consequently, I started analysing the things I did that made the models learn faster or better behaviour and applied the same techniques to me which caused my progress to accelerate. This makes me wonder if one day we can identify how to learn better by simulating all the different ways that Deep Neural Networks can learn

Your analysis of why the hedge funds underperformed the market was entirely wrong imo. It's not because the market is too random (opposite to what you said, that's only true in the SHORT term, not the long term) or because they are not true "experts", but because hedge funds make their money from fees paid by active clients. Clients are most likely to leave a fund when they're losing money, so hedge funds are more focused on avoiding losses than they are on making gains. That's why they overperformed the S&P during the crash, but significantly underperformed it when the market was going up. The hedge funds' incentive is not to make gains, but to avoid losses.

About the 10.000 hours:

Only if a training program is (1) highly efficiently constructed to teach somebody something and (2) is already aware of all aspects of the proficiency, mastery can be achieved in a relatively short amount of time - like 10.000 hours.

On the other hand, native speakers of a language for example, they need roughly 100.000 hours to learn their own language in multiple phases. There is no "Learn Your Own Language Effectively" at all time. It works more like kids are watching cartoon shows on TV for thousands of hours over years.

People who learn a foreign language later on in their life are a great example that 10.000 hours are not comparable to 100.000 hours.
Five years of study time at a university may lead to those 10.000 hours. But depending on the subject, these graduated students would still arrive as freshmen in their new job and are no comparison to 60-year-old experts, who have done all this for 35 years, 40 hours a week - especially by developing their own network of conclusions and methods.

The 4 things.
1. Not everything has a pattern, and it is a waste of time to look for a pattern when one doesn't exist.
2. Repeat until large information is digested into chunks with recognizable pattern.
3. Get in an environment that will rate your interaction, so you know if you are using what you recognized right or not.
4. Make it challenging so you'll become better. Keep doing what you know you can do won't make you become better.

I solve Rubik’s cubes, and have done so for thousands of hours and it is one of the things that has made me realise how possible it is to improve at anything.

I can remember myself getting 30 second times thinking I’ll never be as good as the best to now averaging just under 9 seconds (granted still far away from the best). Those hours weren’t spent just solving however, I have engaged with a lot of the theory behind the puzzle, learning new algorithms, techniques and methods whether or not I ever use them, even inventing and coming up with things by myself and actively seeking out new information no matter how obscure or hard to find. I also tried my hand in all 17 different official events including the most difficult ones such as 5x5 blindfolded and even unofficial events just for fun.

I believe it’s the desire to constantly acquire new information and improve that leads someone to become an expert, and never assuming you know everything or being complacent

There’s also a fifth key factor to becoming an expert, and this impressively insightful video is very incomplete without mentioning it: Level of interest. The person who is interested in learning and becoming better at a particular skill will always be more likely to become an expert, than a person who practices without interest. This is unfortunately seen in our old school education systems, where students are forced to do rote learning and perform in tests, in subjects they don’t have interest in. As a result, even though they might try to always solve new problems and take more tests at the edge of their ability, if they’re forced to do so to pass a grade, instead of out of personal interest, that student will turn out a mediocre performer and will have wasted his/her valuable time.

It's neat to know that I have essentially been doing this without knowing while taking piano lessons. I only put in about 2 hours of effort each week, but that entire time is spent improving. When I'm nearly done learning a song, I'll start to look for other ones that need skills I don't have; and I don't just keep playing the few songs I've learned. For example, I'm bad at large chord jumps right now. I tend to miss my marks, or hesitate, or sometimes rush ahead of the beat. So for my next song I picked out something that is almost exclusively that, but well within my range of skill.
Eventually, when I've made a mistake and picked something too hard for me and I find I'm not making good progress, I'll drop it and change to something well within my wheelhouse to quickly regain confidence.
It's been a highly effective method of learning. I've learned more in the last 100 hours than I have in the last 10 years.

As a finance guy, I think I need to clarify one thing with respect to the hedge fund example: here's the thing, hedge funds are not meant to beat the market. I repeat, the goal of a hedge fund is NOT to beat the market, but to provide SOME returns no matter the market conditions. It's in the name; they hedge risks. In other words, should a financial crisis occur, a hedge fund must demonstrate some growth (above zero, obviously) while a passive investment such as the S&P500 would decline. Hedge funds don't exist for the ordinary folks, they exist for a very small subportion of people/companies that need a specific asset class which would not be affected by the broader market conditions as much & yet generate some returns (i.e gov. bonds are also super safe, but their returns aren't great). Should a crisis come, they don't take a loss on that investment & have money for other purposes if they pull out from the fund.
That being said, hedge funds are often terrible at hedging; and there is also a small minority of funds that provide crazy outsized returns (i.e the Medallion Fund with like 50-60% annual returns for the past decades).

These can feed into each other as well. For example, feedback can come in many different forms: self-evident feedback, like getting a math problem correct; colleague/audience/public feedback; or intuitive feedback, just knowing when something is write. This third type of feedback gets better as you get better. This is especially true for fine arts where taste is very subjective and analytical tools have a harder time telling what is "good". For example, if you're a musician, you might listen to a lot of music, but what is good music and what is bad music? You might have some preconceived idea or get feedback from society, peer groups, etc., and at some point, you'll start to settle on what your taste tells you is good, which will guide you to more music that is good, and let you recognize when your own music is good. This is strange, because you can be in a position where the validity and feedback can both come from yourself. This might be why a lot of artists often like to hide away from people somewhere remote to create.

Does this mean that it is impossible to become an expert on a subjective creative skill, such as art, writing, or acting? From my perspective, it seems like a creative endeavour such as writing has some pretty universal skills to it, which means you can tell a beginner from a well-practised professional very easily... but then moving past that seems impossible, cause the feedback will not be consistent anymore. I found this for myself while getting feedback on a novel from editors and fellow writers - most things they pointed out were contradictory and often correcting a sentence to the liking of one expert meant displeasing the other expert. So you get to a point where you can get feedback that is frequent and timely but vastly inconsistent. You see the same thing in Goodreads comments: comments praising the exact aspect of a novel that someone else criticized or straight up contradicting each other, like one reader saying the plot is too slow and the other saying it is rushed.  Does this mean there are no expert writers, only experienced professional writers that happened to appeal to a very wide audience for whatever reason?

"Anand vs Zapata" after 4 moves of the (fairly) common Petrov's defence tells more about the choice of games by the journalist than the (undeniably amazing) memorization capabilities of Magnus. Just for reference, Anand played this exact sequence of games in 90+ games and Zapata was just one of them.

I wonder how this applies to experts in arts, where the feedback for what you do is more subjective, For chess, feedback comes in the form of finding the most advantageous move or winning the game, and in physics it comes from establishing a mathematically sound conjecture. But in things like art or music, the feedback isn't concrete, as how good something looks or sounds isn't set in stone. There are smaller things certainly; as a musician I can get feedback from how smoothly I play something, but the overall structure, the pattern of notes that I create in composition or improvisation, isn't a defined goal. For a beginning musician, that goal may be in learning to play in key, or learning what notes lead naturally into others, but just as often the best pattern for a composition may involve stepping out of the bounds established by playing in key. For painting, you could on one end get feedback on how realistic your painting looks, but if you're aiming for a style that doesn't prioritize realism, or creating your own style, there's not a clear marker of success. It's not an invalid environment like gambling, but there's still a level of subjectivity that makes it harder to clearly quantify expertise. For instance, just because someone can play something extremely fast, the melodic structure of their playing may be too repetitive or not match the other players if there are any. It would be cool to see a video looking at that side of expertise

Very helpful video, but I think his perspective on the stock market is correct. Invalidity isn't the reason active managers underperform the market. The reason active managers tend to underperform the market is that their goal isn't as much to outperform the market but to convince people to give them money to manage. Often these two strategies are in conflict.

I summarized this video in the statement below. I welcome criticism because I find this video extremely powerful:

expertise is combination of the following 4 items outlined below:

1) Repeated Practice with a way to judge how well we did (efficient - how quickly we reach our goal vs effective - how well the goal was met) and a desire to improve both efficacy and effectiveness.

2) Valid Environment - the outcome of our repeated practice is NOT predominantly determined by chance or things outside our control (gambling, fortune telling, etc)

3) Timely Feedback - We need to know immediately when we've not done as well as we could and have a way to come up with a plan to improve.

4) Never get comfortable - We don't simply do what we already know how to do, we push the boundary to try to do things that we will fail at.

The pattern thing with randomness is what the Monty Hall Problem is based off of! That's why you're more likely to win if you always choose the other one, because rather than trying to beat the pattern you're just relying on pure RNG, which tends to 50%.
silva mind control method.

Based on these criteria, one can become an "expert" too based on biases. The perfect example are police officers, who can be trained on "extra" information which are not just unnecessary but can also lead to undesired performance. But the outcome can be misconstrued as expertise. In fact, our definition of the best police officer, who think on their feet, tends to be biased. We see this too as overfitting in ML training, where "extra" information (Internet dataset) generalizes the model in the wrong direction. Valid environment in this case wouldn't be enough, repetitions/feedback can exacerbate bias, and one can deliberately practice with bad habits. Structured data set that outweighs bias is also needed. And this is subject to whether the "game" has perfect information. Training in chess (perfect information) is different from training in blackjack (imperfect information). A pure blackjack player can be an "expert" based only on the 4 criteria, but is considered an amateur compared to an analytical player who also applies statistics, which helps to structure the data set, and an effective filter of learned biases. In the age of too much information, people who can structure the unstructured...are redefining the traditional notion of "expertise". And Derek is an undervalued example of this. With his concise no-baggage presentation style, gives more clarity on many topics in few minutes than most expert literature.

The finding of patterns where there aren’t necessarily meaningful ones is also something at the heart of a lot of mental health struggles. And I’m not talking specifically about paranoid delusions but all forms of anxiety, depression etc. It very often happens that core emotional needs are not met growing up and we aren’t offered the tools needed to learn things like internal emotional regulation, a solid foundation of self worth, a belief that we can affect change etc. As a result of these early losses, we often try to compensate with our intellect to try to make sense of our own confused emotions. We find patterns where there are none. The conclusion that we lack value, are bad people, have no power etc can be the result of similar false pattern finding to try to make sense of our difficult emotions, a result of lack of tools provided and trauma,  from what is largely a random soup of life’s unfortunate events.

Great content and thought provoking. I'm a radiologist with almost 20 years of experience in breast imaging. I'd like to indicate that our task in breast cancer diagnosis is not to actually determine if a finding is malignant or not. Rather, to look for features that are concerning for cancer, In which case we would do a biopsy. As we try to err on the side of caution, the usaual statistic quoted is that 70% of the biopsies are actually cancers. Therefore, this apparent "low" rate of accuracy is not a reflection of poor performance, nor is it related to a lack of feedback. In actuality each case we biopsy is followed by an accurate pathology report within days. Radiologists are involved in multidisciplenary rounds with our clinical colleagues and we also have internal quality assurance measures to ensure a high level of competence.

Veritasium forgot an important concept in this video about being an expert.  That being considered an "expert" is completely relative to your knowledge/ability compared to others on the subject.   For example, if the highest rated player was actually rated 1600 and you were close to that rating, you'd be considered an expert, even if there's a ton of things you don't know.

In the short term, a stock market is a voting machine, and in the long term a weighing machine. Beating the market consistently in the short term is pretty much impossible, you don't know how people will react to different things (vote). Beating the market in the long term is easily possible if you know what fundamentals of a business are important. Because of irrationalities of markets that result in the first phenomenon (the voting machine) you sometimes get under- and overvalued companies. All you need to do to beat the market is to exclusively buy companies that are undervalued and sell them once they become overvalued. Of course, at this point your activity investing quite a lot of time into the stock market, so you aren't letting your money work for you anymore. If that sounds fun to you then go ahead, for everyone else it's best to stick to index funds.

I want to comment on the stock market portion of the video, hedge funds aren’t trying to get the larger return they possibly can, they are trying to minimize downside risk. Hence the name “Hedge fund” as they are hedging against risk. Hedge funds usually have a huge upfront investment amount into the 10’s to hundreds of millions. These people are looking for maximum growth, they’re looking to preserve their money and prevent it from decreasing. Hedge funds deliver on that need by buying securities that go against their primary investment. I’ll explain this better with an example. Let’s say there are two people, person A and person B. Person A has 10k and Person B has 1million. Person A wants to grow their money as much as possible while Person B wants to grow their money, but with less risk. They both invest into the S&P 500 but person B takes another added step, they also invest into an inverse index like the SQQQ for example that mirrors the market (if the S&P goes up the SQQQ goes down). Person B only invests half the amount he put into the S&P into the SQQQ. Now in the hypothetical situation the year has ended and the Market (S&P) has gone up 10% that year. Person A’s investment goes up 10% while person B’s investment only goes up 5%. This doesn’t look like a very good decision by person B until you look at the opposite scenario. Let’s say instead of going up 10% the market falls 10% that year. Now person A has lost 10% while person B has only lost 5%. This is what hedge funds do. They minimize the possible risks for their clients while still maintaining as much growth as possible. Their clients have very different goals than your average investor and in turn produce different results. To become a hedge fund manager for one of these huge funds you are incredible at your job and could easily beat the market if that was your goal. But it’s not their goal and the hundreds of millions these top hedge fund managers make just for hedging against risk is far more than they would make if they chose to try to beat the market.

FOUR THINGS YOU NEED TO BECOME AN EXPERT
1. valid environment (structured, patterned)
2. many repetitions (not once-in-a-lifetime thing)
3. timely feedback (feedback as soon as you perform an action)
4. deliberate practice (practice outside of your comfort zone, at the edge of our ability, the zone of proximal learning)

The pattern recognition became very clear to me when I learned Morse code. The human brain takes 50 milliseconds to process and understand a sound. People regularly send and receive Morse code at 30 words per minute, which puts the dit character and the gap between all characters at 40 milliseconds. So you literally have to process sounds faster than the brain can recognize them. Over time you start to hear whole words in the code rather than individual letters, but you still have to decode call signs character by character. You basically cache the sounds in your brain without processing them, and once the whole set of characters passes, your brain is able to turn it into an idea and add it to the stack of previous ideas while your ears are already caching the next set of characters.

To learn, the machine needs lots of data, even larger than supervised learning. It needs many observation, or in gaming terms, playtime. It needs valid environment or feedback as a wrong feedback system causes the machine to cheese the system. Great video! Did want to elaborate a bit on the Tetlock research though because not all experts were the same in predicting sociopolitical events!

What Tetlock noticed, broadly, is that experts tended not to do amazingly (as you noted), but there were substantial differences in performance between 2 reasoning styles. He called these "Hedgehogs" and "Foxes." Hedgehogs tended to look at events more simply: They tended to identify broad, singular causes, make more specific predictions, and were more certain in their beliefs. Foxes, in contrast, considered more complex causal pathways with multiple factors occurring at once; they were less specific in their predictions and more likely to identify contingencies in their predictions (if X then Y, but if A then B). Consequently, Foxes greatly outperformed Hedgehogs over the course of the original study. (Tetlock has even been studying so-called Super forecasters--people who consistently get these rare, complex events right--and has foind far, far more fox-ish tendencies than hedgehog-ish ones).

To me, this shows that the social world can be predicted (to a point at least; some events are Black Swans). But it requires a great deal of intellectual humility and deep appreciation for the complex systems of feedback that occur. It's easy to think in simple narratives but what we gain in quick comprehension, we lose in deeper understanding.

I'd say with experience doctors learn to prioritize looking for the most common explanations as they're more often going to be right, and picking the rare randomly occurring disease instead would waste most of their patients' time and money. I think the point is more valid with specialists as their job should be to recognize the more rare conditions.
