My mom studied piano and really liked it - practiced 4 hours a day even though she wasn't aiming at becoming a virtuoso. She studied classical piano so lots of scales, arpeggios and repetitive exercises. The goal of those excercises is to create muscle memory of patterns that arise in pianos scores and my mom, 82, does play never before seen music sheets well at first sight. However, if I giver her a modal (not tonal) piece by Bela Bartok she will have some problems since the training she did was for tonal compositions. Bartók himself realized piano players were "restricted" by the tonal system and published a series of books for piano students with the intention to free them from the major/minor straight jacket. The book series is Microkósmos and starts the second volume with a very simple piece that is not major nor minor - In Lydian Mode.

My mom later studied engineering and became a housewife doing some Math and Piano teaching, working at the community and making us spontaneously hate processed food. Some 20 years ago she decided to learn a set of techniques to teach very small children about music - not the notes but the sounds, silence, noise, high and low pitches. She sudied the Kodály method - developed in communist Hungary during the 1950s by a linguist who was friends with Bartók, Zoltán Kodály. Kodály used some information from linguistics to develop his method and created, among other things, the mano-sofa (a way to do solfeggio using hand signs that was used - incorrectly - in the Close Encounters of the Third Kind film). In a way, both Bartók and Kodály decided to press the red button when they went opposite of the stablished patterns.

There are areas where expertise exists but the subject is so non linear and noisy even making predictions is impossible. Economists, however, often forget about it or try to look more certain about outcomes than they really are and make huge mistakes. We should value those who are unsure, those who recognize the little we know about things and less those who say "humans always behave like this" because that will end up making humans, through practice, become like that. After every crisis in the capitalist develop world there were changes made to the system - except after 2008. The neo-liberals free-marketeers did such a good Propaganda job people started to believe humans are selfish by nature and Government/State only makes the economy go wrong. The US is at the brink of a disaster and it seems leaders - who are not immune to Propaganda - are doing almost nothing to fix that. They all wear that straight jacket of the major/minor scales.

Note: I would distinguish expertise from skill, though¹: Winton Marsallis is a skilled trumpet player who still practices and even has a trumpet coach with him at all times. His coach is probably less skilled than he is in trumpet player but he's an expert is helping trumpet players improve their skill.

It's amazing how analogous to machine learning this is:
- Valid Environment: ML models can't predict randomness, there needs to be underlying structure to the data.
- Many Repetitions: ML models need to be trained over thousands or millions of iterations.
- Timely Feedback: ML models need instant feedback; there needs to be a way to evaluate the performance of a model to improve it.
- Deliberate Practice: ML models need diverse datasets, you can't train it on 1 example, it needs many to generalize.

Besides practicing on the same subject, top performers on their field also have the habit of combining learnings from two or more activities, allowing lateral thinking / creativity to flourish, which in turn expands their repertoires and might give them an advantage against equally prepared competitors. That's one reason not to put your children on a single activity by the age of two expecting that they will become experts, give them room to explore as many activities they show interest in.

I used these principles to develop the Rapid Method for learning a language. Spend less time by learning consistent patterns, using visual mnemonics to build vocabulary, ignoring irrelevant aspects (and dealing with exceptions as a separate activity to be postponed until later). Repetition should always be to embed patterns in memory (esp. “muscle memory” to be able to speak or think phrases automatically), rote repetition is a total waste of time.

I don’t think "stretching" is all that helpful in language learning, though. Everything should be “comprehensible input” as much as possible, and the preparation to learn new material should be to make it comprehensible in advance. Deliberate practice to master weaknesses is, however, crucial. Without out there’s unlikely to be any progress or mastery at all. (In fact, you are more likely to become expert at doing it wrong or making the same mistakes forever!)

Years ago I set out with a mate to complete the Gran Turismo 5 challenge for Nuremberg Ring 24 hour in actually 24 hours without any stopping. This is actually brutally difficult and we spent many weeks learning the track beforehand. To do well, you need to know every corner, the speed, the driving line, the gear, etc. You need to know it well enough to drive at 3am when your exhausted. We ended up learning with this "chunking"; sets of corners in groups from three to five or so. And it worked! I worked at a hedge fund.

The comparison to hedge funds is not totally accurate. The goal of most hedge funds is to "hedge" against the market, not maximize gains. In other words it is to reduce variability. A hedge fund that can consistently return 5% a year with 0.2% variance per year is astounding even if the long term SP500 investment would beat it out overall. The SP500 will beat it with far larger price swings.

The reason so much money goes into hedge funds (charities, union pensions) is because these organizations need to make a consistent ROI to fund certain goals. They can't handle a sudden 20% drop in their portfolio like someone with a 30 year time horizon to accessing that money, they need the money today. So that is why hedge funds get paid their 2/20 fee structure. There is a price to pay for growth AND stability.

Thanks for the fascinating video. I learned about Chess, and got to formulate some of my thoughts around expertise and medicine. I do have a quibble though with your comment about experienced doctors vs medical students on two accounts:

First, number of years is less of a factor compared to what those years were spent doing. Many rare diseases and conditions are such, that if you see a single one in your career you will be able to diagnose it in minutes. I will provide an example I'm fond of this later in the comment. The more time a doctor spends early in their career doing varied tasks and especially overtime, the more learning they're subjected to through varied and complex patient encounters.

Second, the inverse of your conclusion is true today. Medical students tend to avoid overtime and any kind of "uncomfortable" work like being on-call. They tend to see interning and residency as necessary evils on the way to being a "real doctor", as such, they will most likely be objectively worse doctors.

Okay, example:
15 year old male skis down-hill and hits a tree leg-first. The tibia breaks in two parts and the parts become dislodged. He goes into shock, and within an hour or two he is finally at the ICU. The patient is lucid, in pain, and the diagnosis is obvious. The patient is put under anesthesia into a medically-induced coma, the broken bone is realigned, the parts screwed into place, and finally the patient is weened off of the anesthetic and other medications as part of routine surgery.

The patient fails to recover. The doctor knows that this is trouble and seeks out the local neurosurgeon who is on-call. The neurosurgeon immediately orders a chest CT. The CT shows white dots everywhere in the lungs. The neurosurgeon concludes that these are fatty acids from the bone marrow, which have seeped into the bloodstream, and which the blood thinners (given for surgical purpose) have allowed to get everywhere, including the patient's brain. Once the blood thinners were weened off, the fatty acids coagulated, blocking blood flow in critical parts of the brain. The patient makes a full recovery. Why a CT of the chest? Because coagulated fatty acids don't show up well in the brain through CT, and an MRI would take too long to perform in this context.

This neurosurgeon had seen just one such case in his life, decades ago, while interning in another country. Fact is without this experience the patient would've likely suffered severe brain damage. This was not a textbook case, because this series of events just doesn't happen normally. Especially in smaller healthcare centers.

I submit to you that the meme/stereotype of medical students catching rare conditions that "experts" miss, is an example of young, excited, passionate will-be doctors interning in complex care wards, whose chief doctors are less passionate about their craft, to whom it's just a job. I further submit to you that this stereotype is dying, as young doctors today are far less interested in the craft and art of medicine, and far more interested in the glitz, the income, and the status brought on by the title M.D.

That being said the video is excellent. It gives voice to many people who're worried about "experts" whether in economics (Europe's Lost Decade), epidemiology or population health (COVID-19 response or lack thereof), or world politics. People who at the same time follow with great interest "non-experts" - people with education, background and passion, but who've been snubbed by the established institutions.

Hope we can come together more as a world community, and support experts with expertise, not merely titles.

Another thing to note about hedge funds, is their name. They are literally "hedges." As a result, (as you might expect), when the market preforms poorly (such as an index fund), that hedge fund should preform better than the index fund. When the market is preforming well, then it should preform worse than an index fund.
What a lot of people don't seem to understand, is a lot of investing with hedge funds isn't to strike it rich, but rather hedge your money by putting some of it in risky investments rather than having all of it in safe investments. Now, obviously its better to make more money than less, but its been no secret for decades that hedge funds generally don't out preform the market (except in certain rare scenarios, which are usually short lived).
Its actually even far more complicated than I'm laying out here, but I'm neither an expert nor does anyone have the patience to read a long youtube comment about a nitpick about hedge funds. When people strike it big in the market, its almost always luck. That's not to say that you can't make money investing, you obviously can, but anyone getting much more than a few percent more than the averages of index funds is probably cheating in someway or losing a lot somewhere else that you're not seeing.

The kind of expertise acquired by repetitive study through pattern recognition and timely feedback is getting increasingly irrelevant. Computers can do that much faster and more accurately than any human. Memorizing digits of pi, chess and ability to play musical instruments are examples of this very narrow understanding of expertise, but I don't think they can tell us anything about being an expert in (say) social sciences. Being an expert in science does not usually mean being able to accurately predict the future or make the "right" move (or anything else that could be easily quantified). Although the English language misleadingly uses the same word for all kinds of different "experts", it can refer to various disparate things that should be studied separately rather than as one.

Chunking and pattern recognition, although a useful strategy to attain mastery also feed into maladaptive behaviors and traits such as the development of prejudices and the inability to recognize the implications of individual datapoints. Many students of mine are amazed at how I know that the tenor in page 32, 2nd system, bar 1, beat 3 of the Mozart Mass we are learning is singing an E. First of all, there is repetition: I’m teaching that Mass in five or six different classes, so I teach that part at least that many times, or twice or three times that number if I repeat that section in different weeks, often mentioning the page, system and bar numbers. There is also the photographic memory of dealing with that page in particular all those times. But most of all there is the knowledge of the logic of Mozart’s typical melodies, voice leading, chord sequences and chord voicings; I might even not know that note in particular, but if I know that the other three voices have Cs and Gs, I know the 3rd is missing from the chord and therefore must be in the fourth voice. This comes naturally from years of practice in harmony, singing and conducting.

I would argue that experience driving beyond 50 hours does make you marginally better driver.  Remember you are not just driving to stay on the road you are driving around other people.  A person with more experience is more likely to see a person who might try to cut them off for example and learns to spot potential risks and problems and take earlier precautions.  Sure after 50 hours of practice you can keep your car on the road and follow all of the rules without much thought.  But spotting someone about to do something like run a red light, cut you off takes more experience.  Likewise for those of us in colder climates learning how to drive in snow and ice is it's own skill that experience helps with.  That said it's hard to be an expert driver because it's a skill that so many people use so often that it would be impossible to find a small group of people who stand out here...  But I disagree with the implication that you don't really get any better than you are after driving 50 hours.

Since experts in some field tend to do worse than chance, a winning strategy for them would be to make the guess, then say the opposite, no matter how they might feel about it. Secondly, economists get their predictions consistently wrong. Not only a lot worse than chance but probably worse even than self-believing soothsayers and con artists. I've lost count of the daily number of "news" items I hear where "less/more/lower/higher etc. than expected" occur from these people whose advice politicians appear to dote on. Re aptitude tests, on the one occasion I had to select a candidate for a technical job (my field of expertise) from a starting field of 25, I had a single question to ask: if you were given a switching power supply with a blown fuse, what would you do to go about fixing it? The majority (with their glossy multi-page resumes) replied that they would replace the fuse. I instantly dismissed them. The one outstanding candidate (who turned out to be a winner on the job) replied that he would try and discover why the fuse had blown. Right answer! And when I was learning to cook over many years, mistakes were prolific (at first). Now I can bake cakes without a recipe and wonder how I ever got it wrong. Same with baking bread. Every time I see someone performing some mind-blowing guitar etc. (I'm a part-time amateur) I can imagine the thousands of hours of practice they must have put in to get to that level of proficiency. My favourite saying modifies the old saw "practice makes perfect" to the more realistic "practice makes proficient". Perfection is the unattainable target one strives for.

I was a commercial fisherman for a few years, the owner of two boats. I woke up every morning and turned on the Weather Channel. I paid attention because it affected my business. I watched the Weather Channel again in the afternoon, when I came in from fishing, again during dinner, and again before bed. Each day, out on the boat, I watched those blue lines and red lines and triangles and half-circles and purple dashed lines actually move across the sky, uninterrupted by trees or hills. I got to be quite good at recognizing and predicting the weather – better than the professionals who did it while sitting at desks. I was out in it every day.

I paid special attention to hurricanes because I found them interesting. When Hurricane Katrina was moving north parallel to the Florida east coast, a category 1 storm, and predicted to hit South Carolina, I was in Myrtle Beach. I had the Weather Channel on and with more than 10 friends listening – fishermen who pay attention to the weather – I predicted Katrina would stop, turn west, cross Florida, and swing around and hit New Orleans. None of the meteorologists or computer models predicted Katrina doing anything like that. I had predicted every detail for the next 7 days movement of Katrina and we all know where it ended up. It missed my predicted target by just 90 miles. My friend's property in Biloxi was devastated.

Later, I sold my boats and went into a line of work where I was at a desk all the time. Today, I suck at predicting the weather. The point is, when I was constantly exposed to the subject, weather prediction, I became quite good, perhaps an expert. but when I ended the constant exposure and analysis to the information, I lost that expertise.

There's a book called Range by David Epstein that goes into detail on how developing skills like pattern recognition at an early age contribute to success in specialized areas. The book features a chapter where a father deliberately raises his 3 daughters to become chees prodigies of the era, and I highly recommend anyone who's interested to read it. The 4th point that Derek brought up, "don't get too comfortable," is also heavily emphasized in the book, which demonstrates that those who have breadth in a field or a variety of fields tend to have greater expertise.

When I was teaching ESL, I noticed some students would stay firmly in their comfort zone, but then want a lot of feedback from me when there often wasn't much to say. On the other hand, more ambitious students might try to start incorporating obscure grammatical tenses and high level vocabulary which resulted in a lot of "weird" English. I think input and imitation is really important for learning.

I have to disagree with you on the hedge fund argument. It assumes that hedge funds try outperform the market and focus on returns, which is not the case. The defining feature of a hedge fund is securing against general market volatility. Its like a middleground between keeping the cash and investing it long term, where withdraws should be possible at any time with minimal risk of loss. Its usefull for people with a lot of money that waiting for a good opportunity to invest it. If you invest in stocks and get offered a great deal on an asset (ex. a company) while the market is down, you have to choose between selling your stocks at a loss or missing that opportunity. A hedge fund secures against this and reduces the loss in this scenario but thereby limits its profits if the market goes up, so the performace shown in the video is as expected. This scenario actually provides feedback since the reduction in volatility is measurable short term. The fake expert here is the fool that took on Buffetts bet.

Pattern recognition is what makes a good software developer great. Being able to see similarities of new functionalities to old ones and integrating the former to the latter leads to more maintainable code and a more consistent, coherent system. Entropy in software in inevitable and I'm always for burning it all down and rebuilding from the ashe, but understandably that doesn't fly very often because it's time consuming and often doesn't represent a tangible benefit to the people making the decisions, so instead staving off that entropy with thoughtful integration means it's longer before the codebase hits that breaking point and needs a complete refactoring. It also means new functionality is easier to add and integrate.

Microservices sounded like a bizarre idea when I first heard of it at the start of my career but I eventually realized that the core principle behind it is actually at the heart of my philosophy of software engineering: a solid base of reusable, atomic functions can be used as building blocks to naturally and natively create more complex features and capabilities. Done right (which for me means as data-driven as possible), completely new functionalities can be used without having ever coded for them specifically.

Investing is a parasite industry (if you can even call it an industry). They add no value to the economy, they only take, often they directly profit from the losses of others, and to cap it off, as this video shows, they're terrible at the thing they're supposed to be doing. They earn far more than most people who competently do jobs that demonstrably provide a benefit to society: teachers, labourers, retail workers, etc. Why are investors able to earn so much while achieving so little? Because the profits of investing aren't based on workers generating value like other industries, but on the natural tendency of capital to accumulate over time due to interest, economic growth and dividends.

It's like if I owned the sun and charged people money for getting to use it for solar panels or growing crops. As a former violinist who play from  the age of 9 till I was 18, Derek is soo right about being an expert. If you always play or do the same stuff and you're operating within you comfort zone, you'll never get better. It's not until I started practicing an hour a day nearing the end if my time as a violinist that I saw ANY imporvement whatsoever. Likewise, I have played a game called Clash of Clan for 8 years now, and I have a completely maxed out account, but I am nowhere near the competencey of an expert player, nor am I anywhere near as experienced as people who are at the top in terms of almost any vector of game IQ.

For someone who has relied heavily on intuition and long term knowledge throughout my life, it's so crazy to me how the human mind can just learn the wrong thing and accept it as true subconsciously. I think this kind of content is great because it raises awareness in possible shortcomings in cognition, which for me is the use of "active cognition" or the conscious mind in solving problems and decision making. I'm lazy. I've had similar experiences with music as well, once I learn a fun music theory concept or a new song, it's really hard to not just do that same thing over and over again, the reward for feeling competent at that particular thing is powerful. I think the same concept applies to video game speedrunners as well. First of all, I wanted to commend you on providing an excellent, accessible summary of a complex and oft-misrepresented literature! Famous quote: "To the beginner there are many possibilities. To the master there are few." Mastery cuts out the ways of doing things that aren't as good. This sharpens their ability but also ossifies their mind against new ideas. Re: the chess board replication. Practical or random the beginner was doing the same task, but the master's ability to use familiar patterns to compress information suffered in the random layout. The new guy on the shop thinks there are many ways to improve the business, even though those ideas are mostly wrong. The boss thinks there are no other ways and is almost certainly wrong.

As for practice, it helps to "push yourself" but not burn yourself out. If the math problem or guitar lick is too hard you don't take anything from it. Your abilities are a rubber envelope. You want to stretch it with tension but not tear it with force. Drummers for example play a rhythm slowly for 100% accuracy and then ramp up the tempo until they start to come unglued and then relax the tempo again before too many errors happen.

The most amazing and intimidating thing about expertise is not that people do things you could never do but realizing that they are things you might be able to given the input and that they themselves were like you are now when they started.

brief history of HEDGE FUNDS because this guy clearly doesnt get it. early 50s. and the whole point of them, unlike what many people think, is to preserve the capital, rather than making crazy returns. There is something called "market risk" wich refers to the fact that almost all stocks are somewhat correlated with the general markets. meaning that if a bad news comes out and 98% of stocks fall, chances are the remaining 2 percent will be influenced(over simplified but i hope you get it). the market risk is something out of your control, its external factors. enter hedge funds, saving people with billions who dont want their money subjected to market risk. they will "HEDGE" against market risk with complex strategies making the drawdowns smaller, hence the better performance in 2008. see the whole point of them is having no market risk, as little drawdowns as possible and preserving capital, NOT to beat the market( its in the name=hedge). conclusion : they dont beat the market because theyre not supposed to))))))

They can't just hand you a flowchart, telling you what to do and your students will start aceing every exam. Therefore, building a good intuition, based on actual science, will give better teaching results than trying to force one strategy over and over again. Adaptation is crucial, depending on what field we're talking about. All in all, it's encouraging to know it's okay to fail and that failure (with feedback) is the key to success. The famous Hattie study actually showed that a healthy feedback loop is one of the most effective factors for successful longterm teaching.

First off, great job on the video! It's really cool to understand what it really is that makes an expert.

That said, I feel the need to defend the economists, journalists, policy and security experts. It's not these experts aren't knowledgeable or are deliberately screwing up (although recently, some are doing it on purpose). It's just that that the economy, elections, and geopolitics are extremely complex systems where one situation is almost never exactly the same as others. There are simply too many factors in these systems to take all of them into account. So the only options are to either ignore them since they had no bearing on similar events in the past, or better yet, try to recognize all of the as many of the factors at play as they can recognize, evaluate which ones seem to be important in the moment, and guess how a similar event in the past could play out under these new conditions. But of course, no one will always be right.

But that said, a policy expert failing to guess the correct end result isn't the same as a regular Joe Schmoe guessing wrong. An expert might be correct on 80% of the path towards a certain outcome but just miss the final step, but the average person might be just completely wrong. And the average person can guess the end result correctly but likely can't correctly explain WHY that result occurred, whereas the expert would likely know where they went wrong in their prediction.

IMO, I feel like it's kind of dangerous to say that the average person who might only read the news every once in a while knows just as much as a policy expert who has dedicated their life to the study of these complex systems. I think it would be best to think of policy experts as permanently training outside of their comfort zone, dealing with situations that push and challenge their understanding, in hopes that every mistake helps them make a better prediction next time.

In a sense the newer graduates spotting those rare outcomes is possibly the residual Dunning Kruger effect operating in reverse. They still lack the experience to determine the actual likelihood of the hypothesis being true and thus are more prone to the default over exaggeration of the layman. Of course they wont be as oversensitive due to the fact they are aware of more negation factors that rule out certain hypotheses which gives some resistance against confirmation bias. But ultimately for the very rarest of scenarios the lack of experience can potentially be an advantage, this will by nature occur very infrequently, but when the truth is on the edge of normal experience it can help else we do tend to narrow the scope of possibilities to those we have experienced over time. I for example will openly admit that I'd probably never manage to diagnose a modern equivalent of the math bug the intel processors once had. I literally have zero experience of this actually existing and I'd probably reach for difficult to confirm or rule out nebulous sources like RF interference before considering the chip may be defective by design as it is so rare. Suffice to say a lot of labour would be wasted on such a fools errand.

just a side note--a tilted roulette table is not as random as you might think. Doyne Farmer famously built a computer for predicting roulette, which was hidden in his shoe so he could beat the odds at a real casino. He once shared an anecdote where the computer predicted where to place the bet and the roulette croupier placed the same bet at the same exact moment. Apparently the guy spinning the wheel can develop an expert sense of where the ball is going to land.

This is my main concern with climate scientists. I think the theory and general outcome of increasing CO2 concentrations is correct, but specific predictions about timetrames, temperature effects, local effects, extreme weather, or human population repercussions are questionable. There is no way to become a climate expert exactly for these reasons and the retort of "trust the experts" or "the science is settled" is not valid. Some thoughts from my own life and some observations I've made through the years.
1) This video has just deemed Tom Brady as an expert. His combined knowledge of the formations, tendancies and such of the various defenses he faces has become somewhat obvious to him as his longevity and mastery of the game has continued. Now at age 45, with 7 rings, 20+ years of professional game play, "legendary" reputation for game play footage reviews, and more.
Not just the G.O.A.T. but an expert!

2) I played pool at an elite level in my younger years. Often opponents would ask me to "call the 8" at the start of the game. This meant that I would need to tell them what pocket I would be shooting the 8 ball into, thus winning the game. As my time on the tables increased over the years, I realized the game became simpler as the tendancies of the positions of the balls became familiar to me. It made shot selection and strategy much easier. It was other "expert" players that would discuss this "familiarity" with me, as if we had discovered the secret of life, or the cheat codes within the game.

3) Memory is a component of intelligence as the chess expert and the 24,000 decimals places of Pi demonstrate, however it is the sub-conscious brain that allows experts to use what the lay-people call "instinct" and to make decisions at an unconscious level that takes them to "expert status". Memorizing things doesn't make you better unless you allow your brain to show you how to use that information in the decision making process.

As with the khabuda and Trei Weber examples below, we've all come across "experts" in our lives for things most people take for granted. This video should be part of the learning processed for work, sports, and things people like for play and entertainment.

Final Comment: This process of pattern recognition is what also allows expert levels in SuDoku, and solving Rubix Cubes to name a couple. The user is not "solving" so mutch as they are completing the pattern to fruition.

I like to think about the brain as a JIT compiler (occupational hazard), and that jives pretty well with this. You can interpret events piece by piece, or start batching them together, create layers of caches, make weighted predictions. All implemented in the form of a neural network that is the brain. Nature's signal processing capabilities are respectable.

One thing I'd argue though is that the 4th point is really motivation. Motivation/investment is what drives people to try testing limits, including their own. It's a matter of picking a variable to optimize for, for some this is the inherent enjoyment of the activity, for others it's the pursuit of the various limits pertaining to the activity.

This explains why there are entire types of roles / job ladders in business and management which are difficult to get better at.
* There is no valid environment - because despite putting in the best effort and right decisions, due to external factors, you might not get the results needed and these factors are difficult to predict.
* The relationship between decisions made and output is difficult to attribute and therefore easily derided or dismissed.
* Feedback surfaces after a long time lag (if any) and focusing on that decision-to-output chain of events is nearly non-existent.
All of this makes it difficult to discern patterns and improve. Explains why B-schools resort to case studies. Always cracks me up when teams who operate in more 'easier to build expertise' ones throw shade at those where expertise is hard to build!

Typing is a better example that driving, I'd say. When you are first starting out, you have to think where keys are and how to spell words. After many tens of thousands of hours, it is like talking. You don't think about anything other than what you want to say.  Back when I was in high school, I was absolutely mesmerized by this woman who worked in the library typing out the card catalog cards. They had random characters from the Dewey Decimal System, yet she was hammering these things out at over 100 words a minute on a MANUAL typewriter! When they finally got her an electric typewriter, she had to slow down because she was typing faster than the motor would clear the keys, so they would jam. Then they got an IBM Selectric that couldn't jam like that, and she clocked in at over 190 words a minute—and could carry on a conversation at the same time!  Even though I can type now without having to think about anything other than what I want to write, I can't come close to that speed or carry on a conversation simultaneously, and I've been typing every day for over 50 years. There is some natural ability that some people have that is just how their brain is wired genetically.

I've played piano for many years, and the trick with deliberate practice is finding the right "distance" to go out of your comfort zone. Just outside your comfort zone, it isn't too big a deal. But if you go too far out, you're overwhelmed, panic and frustration will impede improvement. It's difficult to find the proper "distance" out of the comfort zone, it's very abstract and requires a lot of trial and error. It would be interesting to see a video explaining how to optimize reaching out of the comfort zone.

The chess masters recognizing actually possible states of the board but not random impossible ones signifies that to the chess masters, a state of the board means something, while to beginners, it's just a random one of thousands of possible states the chess board system could be in. The same way that a letter or a word means something to those who read that system of writing, instead of just being a random one of infinitely many series' of lines on a page.

You can see an interesting artifact of this in recent AI art systems like DALL-E or Midjourney, where they can generate shapes that are suggestive of text, even of text in a particular font, script, language, etc... but it's not *actually text*, not actual letters combined into actual words used by any language. It's meaningless nonsense to us, who are expecting meaning beyond the superficial, but to the AI, eh, it looks about the same as any other imagery of this kind, what's wrong with it?

Well, I had a very similar experience (3:30) when I tried sudoku for the first time and in under 2 days I was already playing the grandmaster level averaging completion in 30 mins from almost 2 hours on the begginers level from when I started and I'm definately no expert in sudoku. When I started, all I saw was numbers. The more I played, the more it looked like an incomplete recognizable pattern (easier to process) instead of a puzzle. Being an expert in something is literally selling your soul to that cause, the only diff is many can live with that decision and it's better than actually making a deal with the devil; with any transaction comes a cost (time) and benefit (skill). This brings me to the point that being an expert is not neccessarily the best way in life even tho you might love it so much and at the same time not wish for better because being good at multiple things is always better than being an "expert" in just one. I think alot of people struggling with focus or what is called ADHD isn't as the media makes it seem because as long humanity has existed, these types of people have lived and excelled in society. I see it more as people being too bored/losing interest with a particularity ( school, work, sports etc..) and not necessarily the ability to focus. Because when presented with constant changing activities in a shorter period ( 2 to 3 years), they significantly perform better at the multiple streams when evaluated than when they are given just 1 particular activity for the same amount of time. In the latter they tend to peak, then plateau and then ofc decline not only in capacity for that activity but also in the overall interest towards that activity. So if being an expert is your thing (10+ years of the same thing while constantly maintaining interest), well go ahead and do your thing. We can't forget the financial benefits that is rewarded to expertise in demanding fields which is always a bonus. And so If you're struggling with focus on a particularity, try switching it up or completely. It's perfectly fine to move on to something else once every couple of years as long as you can afford the cost of changing. Expertise in some sense can be a dedicated form of slavery, and so I try to always follow purpose which is not set by me but by my creator. There is not a particular way to life, but one in "purpose" can be agreed to be the pinnacle of the physical human existence.

Same ideas work for training Neural Networks. Especially for teaching them to play games (reinforcement learning).

1. Valid Environment = Regularities in data
2. Many repetitions = Size of dataset
3. Timely feedback = Gradient descent as a feedback. Run gradient update after each batch of data.
4. Deliberate practice = Diversity in data (data augmentation)
The 10,000 hour figure is based on world champions in extremely competitive fields. The base-level proficiency most people would be interested in only takes about 40 hours.

Love your videos, but the Wall Street example is flawed. Hedge funds attempt to reduce risk, not beat the averages. It would be like saying buying health insurance is a bad investment if you didn't get sick in a given year, which misses the point of buying insurance.

The plain bagel recently did a great video on hedge funds which explains this point.

The often quoted statistic of 80% of managed funds not outperforming the index is deceptive, as many are not attempting to outperform the broader index. Rather, different funds have different purposes. Some attempt to reduce market risk (at the cost of returns). Others concentrate on companies paying higher dividend yields for those looking for income. While others are concentrated in a particular industry. These are just a few examples.

If you think oil will rise, you have available to you several funds only concentrated in oil and gas which you can invest in. However, if oil goes down while the broader market goes up, it's hard to blame the funds for that. They simply provide the vehicle to investors that want to concentrate investment in that industry.

The topic was covered there with a chapter about a study where experts (professors, economists, scientists, politicians, journalists, CEOs, etc) were found to have a completely unrealistic view of their knowledge and abilities when compared to the average person. Great video. Question, though. Do you think that anyone could be the next Magnus Carlsen (for example)? Let's say you trained a young child to play chess and that child put in the exact amount of training and effort (with the 4 criteria you mentioned) as Magnus, do you think he'd be even half as good? I'd have to think that there are some genetic factors helping Carlsen out here. I mean, he regularly plays against chess player with as many (if not more) hours of qualified practice than him. At 13 he was a grand master and beating players well over 2 or 3 times his age. I get that there is a difference between being a competent expert vs one of (if not) the best in the world at something. However, I feel like the problem with focusing so heavily on this perspective - as well as with Gladwell's book, is that the standard used to be an "expert" at something is really just being one of the absolute best to ever do it. It's one thing to be a really good, even accomplished, musician and another to be Beethoven. For example, Gladwell cites the Beatles in his book, not other talented bands from around that same time, like The Everly Brothers - even though in most respects it could be argued that The Everly Brothers were better technical musicians - and they certainly had an influence on the Beatles. Surely there has to be a large social and cultural element that leads to a "right place at the right time" reason for success in many cases as well as genetic abilities that play into excelling at something.

This was a fascinating video, thank you! There is something tangentially related to this that I have always been curious about - something I've colloquially named "Assisted Memory Recall" for lack of a better term. Basically, I'm talking about the common, everyday way you can't remember something until the memory has been triggered. We do this all the time, but I think the easiest example is musicians. Many performers, regardless of hours of practice, will still not be able to perform a piece without the sheet music, much less be able to transcribe the piece from memory. However, if you let them look at the sheet music, they are suddenly familiar with every note, every phrase, and they could point to things they couldn't transcribe and give insight on the way those phrases are supposed to sound and be played.

Lots of scifi will lead you to believe that every bit of your human experience is still in your brain and with the proper tools or psychotherapy those experiences can be unlocked. That's obviously a fairy tale, however there is something esoteric and almost magic about the way that we store and recall information so that we can interact with a foreign system in a familiar way, so that the performer is familiar with how to play the notes in a passage without them being committed to working memory.

Another example - remembering the lyrics to a song after hearing the first few bars

the way a lookup table that you use frequently feels familiar, but you still need to reference it. "What is the output for 16 again? oh that's right..."

The way you can't blindly recall all the videos you watched today, but if you look at your history you can give insight/feedback about each one.

My brain does this several times a day and it's the closest thing to magic I've ever seen. As much as I love the mystery, I'd love the closest thing we have to an explanation

Being a chess master myself, I can tell you memorization skills are part of intelligence. I know chess players who have played thousands of games and still can't memorize anything. They can't recall their own moves even immediately after the game. When the best players in the world see a position somewhere, they can tell you years later where the pieces were, how the game went on and what would have been the best moves. I'm somewhere in between. I memorize a lot, but I forget a lot of the details over time if I don't refresh. While in chess you need a high rating to be considered an expert, in other disciplines there are other criteria. E.g. you are a "professional" if you make a living from it, while you are an "amateur" if you do it for free. Some amateurs are more competent than some professionals, but the amateurs are never asked for expertise. Would you accept an amateur as an expert witness in court? To be interviewed as an expert on TV, you don't need to be competent at all, but you need connections and you need to support their agenda. Also missing in the video is the impact of personal interest. If you're not interested in a topic, you can spend hours and hours and not memorize anything. We all know that from school.

No, honestly:

This just shows a problem in the way we think about expertise.
I would call myself a master in design and illustration and in this branch there are so many people that mistake experience with expertise.
A lot of people just don't think - they just rely on what they learned in the past and that's it.
They meet all the criteria "valid environment", "many repetitions" and so on.

But in the end - honestly -, there is no mastery in what they do.

They would say they are masters and someone that doesn't know a lot about the topic from the outside would think so too - but they really are not.
They have only done the first step.

A master is able to see things outside of the past experience, outside of the already learned.
And this is the problem with this definition of expertise. A true master can evaluate and simulate situations in his head that are completely new and learn from that - and there is no repetition needed.
You are only a true master if no one can feedback on what you do except yourself.

In some jobs, it is enough to just do some things for a long time and get some feedback along the way, but in others, you need to be able to overcome your experiences and truly evaluate them instead of just learning from the obvious results.

Very informative and inspring video! I want to share a story I have, related to this. It tells how those 4 criteria came together for me once, and how I started to improve in a competition.

A while ago, I started playing Brawlyhalla, and I was hoping to play it competitively(I quit it). It's just a fighting game. If you fight well, you win.

*It was a regular environment*, because results were decided with clear game rules.

In something like my first day, I was pressing keys almost completely randomly, and hoping to do something that works. At the same time, I had an experience in my life: in a new situation, reflexes will not work. You may panic and try other reflexes, but they will also fail you. What you should do in such a situation is to calm your brain and try to get quality information about the situation, and derive the action plan using much more general knowledge, like laws of physics instead of how to hit a volleyball; for example.

So, this knowledge I had was in my mind. In something like my second day, I slowed down. Yes, not trying to hit the opponent or running away may not help in a fight. But I started *practicing deliberately*. And I got my *timely feedback*: I noticed how some strategies were giving very good results, while getting too excited and going back to random key presses were pulling me back very quickly; even in a very good situation.


After a few days of *somewhat many repetitions*, I was really climbing the ladder; tier by tier. The improvements in my gameplay was very clear, and I was only losing momentum when I get too excited or tired or etc. In my early days of deliberate games, I even felt like I was way above that tier, instantly. It was like I had dropped from a very high tier, while I was that tier's player a day ago.

Sadly, I was always getting too sweaty while playing that game. So sweaty that it was becoming unbearable for me. So I quit at something like 1200 ELO, or something. I still cannot play fighting games like that. They are just too intense, and my body gets hot internally, even if I don't get too excited.

If we had unfettered access to System 1 whenever we needed it, ability acquisition would undoubtedly be easier. But our brains let System 2 strategies intercede once we become steeped in this method of learning. Infants lack the level of cognitive development needed to learn the logic of operational grammar or the complexities of phonological systems through a System 2 approach. But they can acquire pragmatic competence in language communication very quickly through pattern recognition. Two decades later they might try and acquire a second language through deliberate practice. But it's not nearly as effective and outcomes are often disappointing.
One of the reasons so many of us don't achieve high levels of proficiency in our abilities is that we are innately attracted to the learning strategies that provide the most IMMEDIATE feedback rewards. Getting to the higher echelons often requires a strategy that produces no noticeable gains for quite some time. There's a Marshmallow-Test aspect to virtuosity.

For learning to be an expert, other aspects are important. Ongoing curiosity. Constant questioning. Intentionally working to ‘break’ what you ‘know’. Exploring all sorts of topics unrelated to your chosen field. The ability to see similarities across disciplines and fields to then use insights from each to challenge the others. A lack of fear of failure while still working to avoid it. Understanding limits of knowledge. Knowledge of fallacies and logical failings of all sorts. Etc…. And not only to be prepared always to chuck what you thought you knew, but to actively look for how you actually got “it” wrong, even though you think you got “it” right. That involves constantly looking for new solutions to old problems, new ways to solve old problems, and with all of those searching for flaws in your knowledge, or perception. Challenge perception and existence themselves. Challenge the fundamentals - always.

For example, we have “known” since Einstein that gravity doesn’t exist. It isn’t a force. It is the observed relationships that fall out of applying Newtonian motion in curved space time. The ‘force’ relationships are relationships only because they are artifacts required by the geometric construct of space time combined with conservation equations. And this doesn’t just apply to gravity.

We develop shorthand’s for what we think we know, even with “firm” equations like the gravitational field equation. And then we neglect to challenge our beliefs. We then get stuck..

When we learned about DNA we concluded that knowledge could not be passed down from parent to child genetically. Only now much later looking at methylation, acetylation, phosphorylation and more do we realize that epigenomics, proteinomics, and other means exist to code information through a lifetime and to then have that information passed on to progeny by changes associated with the genome, while not changing the genome itself.

We learned that bacteria and other organisms extend tubules between one another and ‘share’ plasmids and other bits of programming and information across enormous evolutionary boundaries so that each may gain from competing with and simultaneously sharing with others. E..g. Antibiotic resistance.

We learn that a massive fungal network exists and pervades the biosphere swapping nutrients, water, minerals and much more. We do not even know the bounds of that yet.

Through out it all, we learn that we know, actually know, much less than we thought we did.

Humans have way more problems with long lag times if they don't document things and don't attempt to learn from their predecessors' mistakes.

You can improve a lot regarding timely feedback if you keep records and go back from time to time to effectively back-test things (assuming the distribution is similar). It's why e.g. aircraft are required to maintain such good records. In the event of an accident one needs that data + expertise to obtain an estimate over probable causes which despite the often very long lag times, allows one to learn about design flaws that may have been implemented 10+ years ago. Without those records the number of possible causes grows dramatically over time and learning why a plane crashed is basically impossible.

The summary for this video is that the structure of your data fundamentally limits the ability to generate robust inferences. Aside from timely feedback these all have statistical analogues which lead to garbage in, garbage out or fundamental limits on accuracy. You could be a super-human AI but without the right kind of data hard limits will exist on what you can predict.

As a chess fan, someone who plays constantly on-line but reeeeeeealy far from being a master, I can say that conscious practice makes a real diference:
In chess, we have what we call time controls, that means how long a game will take. Most people play blitz chess, a game in which each player has 3 minutes to use during the whole game. Some people like to play bullet chess, that means a 1 minute game.
I prefer rapid (15 minutes per game), because I can focus more.
While in blitz and bullet games our system one takes over, and we play the moves by instinct (like shown in the video), during rapid games we think longer, and it improves a lot our performance.
If a chess player wants to really improve, they should play classical games (90 minute games).
You would learn more from ten classical games than from 1000 bullet ones, even though more time is spent on the bullet part.
The system two is what actually makes us improve!

Do you need these four things?
No, well at least a machine with sufficient memory for the task at hand won't. A machine would only need a "valid environment."

The four things:
1. Valid environment (learning something valid rather than, for example, something random)
2. Many repetitions (with good feedback)
3. Timely feedback (so you can relate with the learning)
4. Deliberate practice (don’t get too comfortable)

The video essentially explained the general Dunning-Kruger effect, though I'm not a fan of the chart. Repeated attempts with feedback forces you to specialise in optimal strategies for the necessary tasks (eg. the basics), and gives confidence in your ability. A valid environment gives you the necessary feedback on failure and a target to further improvement. Timely feedback returns confidence in optimisation by introducing reinforcement on what you have already learned. And the "Don't get too comfortable" phase essentially puts you on real expertise, which is validating your core knowledge on adaptability. That part is essentially what does make the experts.

Hedge Funds typically aim to have a low beta (<1). This means they are less volatile than the market - they go both up and down less than the market. Idea is it may only give you 7% instead of 10% in good years, but it (hopefully) returns (20%) instead of (40%) in bad years.

This is because Hedge Funds are designed to Hedge risk, not to generate absolute returns. In fact HF view their performance through alpha (excess gains generated with a given beta), not beating the market.

I wish everyone understood that HF are not just stock pickers.

Well… this is pretty good and it’s hard to choose what to say in a video like this (V does a great job of curating these videos). But, there was some significant cherry picking of data here (for example radiologists only make 4% errors IRL, the presenter was citing data from experiments on abnormal distributions of films). And, more importantly, to my mind, the message of the video misses the point. Gladwell’s 10,000 hours thing, and even the 4 additional requirements suggested here are all arbitrary hand-waving. The real problem with expertise is that it is assessed subjectively, by other experts, who give the same performance different ratings before and after they (the judges) eat lunch. That is, there is no objective biomarker for expertise. Until there is, these discussions and interesting and maybe even insightful, but not truly useful because the measures are arbitrary, impossible the quantify, and therefore not definitive.

Interesting you brought up the subject of "experts" - I have recently been thinking about the term "scientist".
You cannot call yourself a "doctor" unless you have a PhD or are an MD, you cannot call yourself a CPA unless you pass an exam and are accredited (same with attorneys at law), however "scientist" is a term that commands lots of respect, and if someone claims to be a scientist, you would automatically differ to them for expertise on a scientific subject rather than another bystander. And unlike the term "expert" which has lost its validity somewhat due to misuse (i.e. how can one be an "alien expert", yet there are people who call themselves that), scientist is still a title that is held in high regard.

HOWEVER - there is no official criteria one must meet to be a scientist, there is no exam you can pass, no education you can work towards to be recognized officially as a "scientist". To be a "scientist" it seems you simply need to do professional scientific work (much like a "professional model" is someone who gets paid for photoshoots) which seems like such a low bar to pass. The dictionary definition is even LESS demanding - "a person who is studying or has expert knowledge of one or more of the natural or physical sciences", so according to Oxford dictionary, you don't even need to have expert knowledge of the subject, you could simply be studying. By this definition, every student in any biology class is a scientist. Heck, every kid doing a KiwiCo experiment is a scientist.

I got into this rabbit hole when I tried to look up if Bill Nye is actually a scientist. I then discovered that (in addition to "yes" as the answer to my question) there is no concrete, accredited criteria for being a scientist, which blows my mind.

These 4 criteria are equally applicable to Reinforcement Learning AI systems. The famous example is AlphaGo that beats the human champion at Go. More bespoke formulation for AI systems would look like:
- valid environment with consistent reward signals
- a lot of samples, self-play if possible
- better "reward shaping" that would break down big rewards into a set of smaller "breadcrumb" rewards along the path to success
- a lot of electricity ($) to train the model!

As a musical professional, the chess board memory test is very relevant to how I operate. I often need to be able to play a song after 1 listen. I don't have an incredible memory, or even a very good one... it's about contextualizing the information in a meaningful way. If I hear that the chord progression is a I IV ii V and I know the key is A, that gives me a lot of information. If I have to do a 7th scale off of each, I'm thinking:

I = A C# E G#
IV = D F# A C#
ii = B D F# A
V = E G# B D#

This is not me memorizing 16 individual values. If you gave me 16 random notes, I don't think that I'd be able to reliably repeat them back, but in this context it couldn't be easier for me.

Interestingly, this shows the immense value of AI in our future societies as the true expert(s):

1) Repeated attempts with feedback, an AI has the longevity to store data and repeat experiments. It can read our entire history and remember it all. No human can. Humans have a limited lifespan, and can only store so much expertise within their life, and can hardly pass it to new generations (if at all), who would have to start over again.

2) Valid environment, i.e. no randomness. An AI however can recognize randomness much easier than a human brain can, and act accordingly.

3) Immediate/delayed feedback is not applicable. To an AI, both are the same. Timescales are a non issue, the AI won't care when it gets the feedback, as long as it will.

4) Comfort. Again n/a to an AI. AI will simply follow mechanisms to explore the boundaries of its knowledge, it does not need 'to leave the comfort zone'.

With JWST and LHC showing us how wrong Newton is...shouldn't we swap to Leibniz?

[Exhibit A]:

We have ten whole, rational numbers 0-9 and their geometric counterparts 0D-9D.

0 and it's geometric counterpart 0D are:
1) whole ✅
2) rational ✅
3) not-natural ✅
4) necessary ✅

1-9 and their geometric counterparts 1D-9D are:
1) whole ✅
2) rational ✅
3) natural ✅
4) contingent ✅

Newton says since 0 and 0D are
"not-natural" ✅
then they are also
"not-necessary" 🚫.

Newton also says since 1-9 and 1D-9D are "natural" ✅
then they are also
"necessary" 🚫.

This is called "conflating" (similar words but different definitions) and is repeated throughout Newton's Calculus/Physics/Geometry/Logic.

Leibniz does not make these fundamental mistakes.

Leibniz's "Monadology" 📚 is 0 and it's geometric counterpart 0D.

The Egyptians, Syrians, Greeks, Mathematicians, Plato (the Good on 0D-3D pyramid) and don't forget Jesus and John all speak of the Monad (number 0, geometry 0D, quantum SNF).

0D Monad (Quarks)
1D Line (Leptons)
2D Plane (Guage Bosons)
3D Volume (Higgs Boson)

We should all be learning Leibniz's Calculus/Physics/Geometry/Logic.

Fibonacci sequence starts with 0 for a reason. The Fibonacci triangle is 0, 1, 2
(Not 1, 2, 3).

Newton's 1D-4D "natural ✅ =
necessary 🚫" universe is a contradiction.

Before we're here is necessary.
This is contingent.
Most likely "imaginary" in the same way 'time' is "illusory".
There's no 3D anybody without their 0D Monad/Soul. No Higgs Boson without Quarks.

Natural does not mean necessary. Similar, yet different.

Not-natural just means no spatial extension; zero size; exact location only. Necessary.

Newtonian nonsense will never provide a Theory of Everything.

Leibniz's Law of Sufficient Reason should be required reading 📚.

This 'low validity' of the stock market you talk about from a theoretical economic perspective is due to the 'efficient market hypothesis', which says that prices always reflect all available information, i.e. there are no ways to consistently profit. The pattern recognition became very clear to me when I learned Morse code. The human brain takes 50 milliseconds to process and understand a sound. People regularly send and receive Morse code at 30 words per minute, which puts the dit character and the gap between all characters at 40 milliseconds. So you literally have to process sounds faster than the brain can recognize them. Over time you start to hear whole words in the code rather than individual letters, but you still have to decode call signs character by character. You basically cache the sounds in your brain without processing them, and once the whole set of characters passes, your brain is able to turn it into an idea and add it to the stack of previous ideas while your ears are already caching the next set of characters.
